div.p: Love's a Jest. A COMEDY, As it is Acted at the New Theatre In Little-Lincolns Inn-Fields. By his MAJESTIES Servants. Written by Mr. Motteux.
LONDON, Printed for Peter Buck at the Inner-Temple-Gate; John Sturton at the Post-Office; and Alexander Bosvil at the Dyal in Fleet-street. MDCXCVI.

div.head: To the Right Honourable CHARLES Lord CLIFFORD OF LANESBOROUGH.
div.p:
I Humbly▪ Dedicate my first Endeavours for the Stage to your Lordship, whose powerful Patronage so generously supports it. The Ancients thus devoted the first Fruits to their Tutelary Divinities. 'Tis true that what I offer comes from a foreign Plant, and is not ripen'd to that Delicacy that shou'd recommend it to your exquisite Taste: Yet I hope your Lordship will be kindly prejudic'd to a liking of the Fruit that was produc'd where you reign. While your Wit and Judgment aw'd me no less than your Greatness, your indulging Smiles embolden'd me to the honour of this Address. 'Tis to that condescending Goodness that I presume to Devote this Essay, as an Earnest of what I will strive to do, to gain a better Title to your generous Encouragement. Nor cou'd I easily have secur'd a Patron to so general a
Satire, had I not happily fix'd on your Lordship, whom all allow to be not only free from the Defects it exposes, but enjoy'd with all their opposite Perfections. Thus your very name will stamp a value on the Piece, and recommend it to the most Difficult, who will fear to mislike what they'll know has been grac'd and made authentic by your favourable Reception.

Here, my Lord, the Custom of Dedications calls upon me, prompting me to put on the Poet, to draw the Patron; and though most Performances of this kind are as full of Flattery as the Plays are of Satire, I might attempt your Lordships Character without being obnoxious to that Censure. But what Pen will dare engage so Lofty and Difficult a Theme? Some of the Best have modestly declin'd it, and been reduc'd to speak like the rest of the World, who strive to give some Idea of your Lordship, by that of The Fine Gentleman; a Character you maintain among the Brave, the Witty, and the Fair, by so undisputed a Title as confirms you a living honour to your great Ancestors, even to the glorious Name of Boyle, that has so long been an honour to this Island and its Neighbour. There are sublime Beauties that admit of no shadow, which, like the Sun, dazzle even while admir'd by Reflection: Things so conspicuous are not to be illustrated with Ink. Besides, I ought to consider that I speak of you to your self; and tho' you still most unwillingly suffer your self to be mov'd out of your admirable temper, 'tis known how dangerous 'tis to make you exert your Patience beyond the Bounds
you prescribe it. The Bravest are the most modest; thus Praise too often offends those to whom 'tis most due, and they shun it no less than they seek to deserve it. This Consideration, my Lord, checks my presumptuous Zeal, and confines me to a silent Admiration of that Worth, which, as it endears you to all mankind, makes me ambitious of being known,

closer.signed: Your Lordships most Humble and devoted Servant, Peter Motteux.

div.head: PREFACE TO THE READER.
div.p:
I Am almost asham'd to mention the extraordinary Success of a Play which I my self must condemn; yet I am glad I was not mistaken in my opinion of the generous Audience, which was so indulgent, that I'm willing to think I was the more kindly us'd for being a Stranger. I will strive to deserve the Favor better by attempting something more correct than this Play, which, tho it makes no unpleasant Figure on the Stage, and is thought sufficiently entertaining, is not altogether dispos'd as I cou'd have wish'd. For, I would have the Plot, Conversation and Humour begin and run through the whole Play together, a thing but seldom practis'd of late. I cou'd not follow that method in this, because I began it upon two Acts suppos'd to be written by a person now dead, and given me by Mr. Verbruggen. Though there is no manner of Business in 'em, nor the least prospect of any, I lik'd 'em so well as to continue 'em and fit a Plot to 'em, but as the Lovers were not brought together yet, and there are none but genteel Characters in 'em, I was oblig'd to make my three Acts so very long, that (when I brought 'em to be acted) without the other two, they were found to exceed by above an Act the due length of a Play. This oblig'd me not only to strike out intirely Mr. Verbruggen's two Acts, but to shorten mine, and with some alterations make 'em Five. I also alter'd some Characters that I might use those two Acts another time: (For, I think 'em too pretty to be lost.) But I have not borrow'd the least word or hint out of 'em; for, tho there is a satirical Wit and a mercurial Spark in them, as well as in this Play, they are somewhat
different, besides those are general humours which almost every Writer takes a priviledge of bringing in where he pleases. I thought my self oblig'd to say so much, because some People either maliciously or through a mistake have reported that the two first Acts are not mine. I am willing to own a Debt, when I borrow, contrary to the Example▪ of most Dramatick Writers. Plantus and Terence borrow'd from the Greek; I wou'd borrow, from my own Countrymen, but Moliere and most of 'em have been so glean'd, that there's scarce any thing left. I have far'd better among the Italians, for I must own my self indebted to 'em for the hint of the two Scenes where Love is made in Jest, as also for some Speeches and Thoughts here and there, and were their Author known I wou'd name him. When ever any thing in foreign Plays will seem to me fit to divert us here, I will freely make use of it, and as freely acknowledge it. Mr. Shadwell said very justly, that we do not borrow from Foreigners out of Poverty, but out of Laziness. Nor will I value the base and notoriously false Insinuations of envious impotent Poetasters, and, least of all, those of a pitiful conceited noisie scribling wou'd-be-quack, below naming; one whose wretched Riddles, Songs, &c. were deny'd a place in my late Miscellanies, tho, like other things of his, recommended by himself, as if written by a Lady. Such an invidious Traducer is well coupled with an idle sharping Dialoguemonger, whose Zany he is; like him, so base as to detract, in the most barbarous manner, from those who never wrong'd him, and so cowardly as to deny it: But they might as well charge those of ruining themselves by Marriage who have not yet committed that Folly, as of ruining a Bookseller by Books, by which he owns he was a gainer: Had I but room, I wou'd stigmatize that Brace of Libellers; for, how despicable soever such Scoundrels may be, they are to be fear'd as well as hated; for, what is more to be hated than a profess'd Lyar, or more to be fear'd than a publick Slanderer.

Let me leave this ungrateful Subject to acknowledge my obligations to Mr. John Eccles, who not only set my three Dialogues to most charming Notes, but humour'd the Words to Admiration; we need not fear Music shou'd decline, while we have so fine a Genius to support and raise it.

div.head: PROLOGUE Spoken by Mr. Bowen in a Riding-Dress.

lg.l: I've been t' invite our Friends at Epsom hither,
But fear we must expect but▪ few this weather.
Here for a triple scarcity we pine,
Of Wits, of Beaux, and what's yet worse, of Coyn.
Lord! what a Croud I met upon the Road!
Try'd Virgins, going to lay down their Load,
Squires, Bullies, Rakes, and Fops, in jolting Coaches stow'd.
Sharpers like Captains; Lawyers Clerks, like Beaux,
And freckled Country-Wives, in new old fashion'd Cloths.
New Married Fools, with hollow▪ Eye and Cheek,
Going to see their Vnkle for a Week,
And batter'd Sinners that have sprung a Leak.
Kind Cuckolds, to see Spouse's Brat at Nurse,
And College Quacks, to purge the Body and the Purse.
Fat Priests, who Coach it while lean Curates drudge,
And their Parishioners on Foot must trudge.
Setters, and Brothers of the Oak and Dice,
And Masks new plaster'd, Cullies to intice.
Cits, who stopt Payment, to take Country-houses;
Some, slyty riding with each others Spouses:
For, Sparks so scarce this time of Action grow,
Cits must e'en Cuckold one another now.
Ev'n Prentices, on Hacknies themselves priding,
Now Whip and Spur to run out Cash are riding:
Then fairly run-away for fear of Chiding.
I fancy, none but those will stay in Town
Who, like us here, want Money to go down.
Let's see! shall we have Charges at this Play?
Faith that's more than some had at their Third-day.
We must Prorogue the House, shou'd this not take,
In Pity then pray spare it for our sake.
A young Play-writer, when we act his first,
Without Damnation here enough is Curst.
Oh! he has then a most Poetic Face,
And looks▪ stay, let me see— just like an Ass;
Nay, what you'll scarce believe, a Poet prays.
Then the next minute, with a frightful mein▪
Vds bloody Bones he crys, they spoil this Scene.
If you seem dull, like him, he's mighty sick,
Cut off a Line, you cut him to the quick.
At the least hiss you'd swear his Soul were fled,
But a round Clap can raise him from the Dead:
He's Cock-a-hoop, and scarce can talk to you,
E'gad he crys, I knew the Play wou'd do.
But if another hiss his Ears but reaches,
Down sinks at once his heart into his Breeches.
Yet scorns our Writer threatning Foes to fear;
The generous Britons will a Stranger spare:
Thus low the Frenchman bows— then learns of you to dare.
His Satire bites but like a Lovers kiss,
And none of you, he's sure, can tak't a miss.

div.head: THE EPILOGUE.

sp.speaker: Mr. Underhil.
sp.p: NOw for the Epilogue.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bowen
sp.p: There's none I think!

sp.speaker: Mr. Underhil.
sp.p: Let down the Curtain then, and let's go drink.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Mynns, one of the Gypsies.

lg.l: ——— Hold!
I must here tell Fortunes e're you stir;
For I'm a Gypsie, tho no Conjurer.
First, Criticks, here in pain you'll always sit,
And swear, all'● as Damn▪ d stuff, as tho by you ' iwere writ▪
You'll strive not to be pleas'd, and, while we 're playing,
Asses will chat, or hiss instead of Braying.
Poor Masks, who lay out half Crown to get Cully,
You'll often sit alone damn'd Melancholy.
You'll Paint like Hell; but yet you'll have some grace,
In this lewd Play-house, you'll ne're shew your Face.
You, Rakish Sparks, shall jogg from House to House,
Look big, shift Boxes, and not pay a Souse.
When drunk, you'll reel out with some tawdry Miss,
And, when at last sh' unmasks, to drink, and kiss,
Sh●'ll cool your Courage with her damn'd old Phiz.
Or, if you're kind, she'll prove a grateful Wench,
She'll get the Guinea, but you'll get the French.
Tho the price of some Flesh is out of Reason,
Whores will be cheap, but ticklish ware this Season.
Close Sparks, who in our Gall'ry lead lewd lives,
You'll pick up Masks, yet dread they'll prove your Wives.
And, you, their wives, will vow you go to pray,
When you're at this or at another Play.
You Vpper-gall'ry Beaux, may hope to find
Masters wise as your selves, some Ladies kind,
And your Sons in the Coach, while you're behind.
You nice Gallants, (I dare not call you Beaux,
That's threadbare, like your Cast-off-wenches Cloths)
You'll still be Beaux, and, while you're lash'd in Plays,
Cry, Dem the Clapping Mob; smile, and take snuff with grace.
Still to pursue the Fairest you'll delight,
Tho you, like smoak, will but offend their sight.
To conquer hearts you'll to the Park repair,
And, while your Prince takes Towns, you'll take the Air.
Bright Ladies, Fortune must your wishes Crown,
You save, or damn us, as you smile or frown;
Save him that spar'd your Blushes here to day;
But Damn his next, if not a better Play!

div.p: Scene Sir Thomas Gaymood's Seat in Hertfordshire.
Time of Action from Noon till Night.

div.head: ACT I.
Scene a Garden.
div.stage: Enter Gaymood Singing: A Servant with him:

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: SLaves to London, I'll deceive you.
E'gad I've as good a voice as most Composers! Prethee sing it me once more, that I may have it right.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Slaves to London, I'll deceive you;
For the Country now I leave you.
Who can bear, and not b●mad
Win● so dear, and yet so bad?
Such a noise, an Air so smoaky,
That to stun yee, This to choak yee,
Men so selfish false and rude,
Nymphs so young, and yet so lewd?

lg.head: II.
lg.l: If we play, we're sure of losing;
If we love, our Doom we're chusing.
At the Playhouse tedious sport,
Cant in City, Cringe at Court,
Dirt in streets, and dirty Bullies,
Jolting Coaches, Whores and Cullies,
Knaves and Coxcombs ev'ry where.
Who that's wise wou'd tarry here?

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Quiet harmless Country Pleasure▪
Shall at home engross my Leisure.
Farewell, London, I'll repair
To my native Country Air:
I leave all thy Plagues▪ behind me—
But at home my wife will find me?
O●yee God's! 'Tis ten times worse!
London is a milder Curse.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Mad Sam Gaymood!

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Covent-Garden Railmore come to ease his Spleen in Hertfordshire!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: What, my thoughtless merry talking old acquaintance, come to eke out a scanty Income with elemosinary Maintenance at an Elder Brothers!

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Even so, by Mercury; and I think 'twas high-time to go after my Credit, when my Credit was gone after my last Quarter. Faith I wisely tick'd for the Coach down, resolv'd the Padders should get no more by Sam, than they wou'd by a cast Poet, when he steals into the Country after his Damnation in Town.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Sure thou might'st have borrow'd of thy acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Of any body sooner I fancy. Why, thou knowest my Conversation is amongst the Wits, and they commonly have too little Money or too much Wit to lend a Brother any thing. Toast me, if I durst so much as ask my man to do it, for fear the Rogue who has formerly carried a Wit's Cloke should ask me Security for his Wages.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Faith I'm come to be your neighbour much for the same Cause; I mean, to recruit, and Dun Tenants, that I may be Dunn'd less my self; for I am not like most of our fine Sparks, that are asham'd of Dunning, but not at all of being Dunn'd.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Prethee, old Wormwood, when did you leave the Town?

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Two days ago, and hearing this morning, my Lord Lovewel wou'd be here to day, I came to see him; but I found him so deep engag'd with your eldest Neice, that, after a moments converse, I e'en left him.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: To come to me: ay, he courts her with my Brothers encouragement, but she's so reserv'd, and he so observant that I dare▪ lay my▪ modesty to▪ thy good▪ Nature (which is no very great Wager▪) that you car'd as little for their Company as they for yours.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Or any body for thine, when there's any other to be got.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: That's like thee! meer Spleen and Envy, Jack, because my Tinsel out-shines thy Lead. Why, there's your Idol▪ Tom Airy, who's come to pass the Summer near us, and is now yonder with my Cousins; he's a pretty smart Fellow, we own it; but, if you'll be judg'd by our Country Sparks, he shines no more when I am by than some slovenly Wit by your glittering Queens of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Why, the little Wit he has is his own, Sam; but thine is as false as their Jewels, and as borrow'd as what they speak on the Stage.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Like thee again! 'Tis well thou know'st I ne're take any thing ill from my Friend— Oh here comes my Brother!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Mr. Raillery! I long'd to have you at my House: Come▪ let's go take another▪ Glass or two of Hock before Dinner!

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: No more till then, Sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why, my neighbour Sir Topewel Clownish and Squire Ilbred who'll be here after Dinner wou'd have made you Topsy before they'd have granted you in Truce.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Ay, they are sonder here of knocking down a Friend, than some of our Bea●-Compainers of knocking down an Enemy.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: A very honourable way of sighting in time of War.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Ay, or in time of Peace either. First, they ply you by Break of Day with a Bumper of Cherry-Brandy to heal you; next two Bumpers of Stingo to to warm you; then as much Mead or Sider▪ to cool you: Stale-Beer and Sugar for Breakfast; a Flood of bad Port for Dinner; an Ocean of worse Punch, for Supper; and a dose of raw Brandy to settle you: Much smoaking, and more drinking; little Eating, and less talking; unless I'm there, e'gad, scarce any thing comes out of their mouths but Smoke.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: But pray what News at London? I shou'd want such a friend as you to send down the News; for your News-mongers are such Lyars!

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Why, truly, in the land of the Wise, they say little; and write less: News is as partially spread as Religions; so, I'm as careless about it as the credulous Croud, or you Country Gentlemen are inquisit●v●.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Yet you may tell one how things go in the City? I hate it as a smoaky Kitchin, but yet good things come out of it sometimes, tho 'tis bad living in 't.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Why, the the City stands where it did; and that's a wonder to the Godly! But the Suburbs are like to overtake you in Hertfordshire: As for the Citizens they follow their own way, I think.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: As how, Pray?

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p:
Why, they cheat, to build Alms-houses; break, to get Estates; rail at Courtiers, yet trust 'em, load Ships, for the Privateers; take Prentices, to learn 'em nothing: Get Money by venturing to lose that of other Folks; take Wives for other Folks, and have Children that are other Folks's. They wear Swords, but never draw 'em: The Court-end of the Town Extravaganue is getting into the City, and the City Trade● to the
Court-end of the Town: They play at the Game of Stock jobbing at the old Exchange, and play away their Money, and their health near the New; Pray for Wealth, but damn themselves to get it; spend little, to leave much; turn Insurers when they've nothing to lose; and Gentlemen when there's nothing to get; lower the price of Goods to make it rise; have store of Bank-Bills, and the Banks, store of empty Chests.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Pray tell us something of the Court? you've been a Courtier, and they say, the best way to have a good malicious account of it, is to ask one that has been turn'd out.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Why, there they are plagu'd with impertinent Suitors, but plague 'em worse with disappointments. Lords sell-off, and Stewards Purchase; just as Officers set up their Coaches, and you Country Gentlemen lay 'em down: Preferments are plenty, but Money scarce: Acquaintances elbow one another out without Conscience, smile without joy, embrace without Friendship, flatter without Moderation, promise without Reflexion, and break their Words without Consequence. Beggers grow Courtiers, and Courtiers Beggers.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Why, that's no news man; begging was the Courtiers Trade from the Beginning.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: But how do thy drink at London now; for there are modes for drinking as well as for other things?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Oh I'll tell you that better than he; first, your Politicians drink Coffee; Wits, Beaux and Women, warm Tea, and some of 'em. cold: We Rakes, drink Red, and then Small-beer; Bawds, Snapdragons; Whores what they can get, but Mead and Rhenish and Sugar to chuse; Stewards the best Champain, and their Masters the worst, Merchants smuggl'd Claret; Wenchers Chocolate, and sometimes Dyetdrink.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: And what do Black-Coats drink?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Oh any thing, any thing.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: I see our two Lovers moving this way, I wou'd avoid 'em, and find out Airy, and the other Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: My Cousin Single, with her Sister Kitty, and my Daughter Christina are that way with him.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: It's a wonder my Lady Single wou'd steal any time from her Books she loves so much, to walk with any of our Sex, she loves so little.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Why, truly there's so little good Society, that Books are often the best Company. It seems the falsness of our Sex has frighted her into an aversion to Marriage as much as the Infidelity of Women has deterr'd me from that fatal Noose; but it grieves me to hear, she impairs her health and good humour by too much reading. I'll strive to perswade her at least not to hate us all, that she may converse with some, and so help me to rail at the rest of mankind.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: Ah Francelia! shou'd your modesty make you doubt your Power of reconciling Libertines to Truth, sure you've too much Charity, not to believe, but some of these may become Converts to constant Love at last.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: At last indeed, and very few I doubt. Some who rov'd in their youth may do at and become constant, but 'tis as most sinners repent, when they grow old, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: Oh! believe me one of those Few that cou'd repent betimes; I sought in others what I've found in you, and have only known their Falseness to prize your worth the more.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I must confess I wish I cou'd believe you, tho yet I think you mean not to deceive me: But in Love's disease▪ as in others, sometimes Libertines seem converted, and make vows, which they then intend to keep▪ but commonly forfeit as soon as they are eas'd.

sp.speaker: ●. Lo.
sp.p: Even Gratitude alone can secure you a heart, but you have Charms to fix a Rover, tho he should want that Vertue.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Alas! my Lord, Love is a sickle Passion, but Beauty is a transitory Charm, and Gratitude a weak chargeable Vertue, which Men shake off, or wilfulfully forget. No, since we must think of throwing away many Favours before we can expect to place one well, I dare not run the venture.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: I swear by all—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh do not swear, my Lord; a Lover's Oaths like Confessions on the Rack, are still recanted, when the Pang is over. If you'll accept my friendship, 'tis your own▪ But name not Love, I tremble at the word.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: Why, Friendship is Love refin'd! Ah! Madam—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Come, we'll walk on, my Lord: I dare not grant you more; and if you prize that Friendship, ask no more: Oh name not Love, I tremble at the word.

div.stage: Enter Gaymood, Railmore, Airy, Lady Single, Christina, and Kitty.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Yonder they're walking!

sp.speaker: Rail
sp.p: And will be these four hours if you'll let 'em: He, only to say, I'll love eternally; and she, I'll never love— Both true alike.

sp.speaker: La Sin.
sp.p: I wonder Lovers are never tir'd of each others company.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: No wonder at all, Cuz; they always speak of themselves.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: As you love to read all day, many love to hunt all day, my Lady Single; now Love they say is a kind of Chace.

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.p: A Wild▪ goose Chace.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: And the Woman the Goose, when 'tis caught the Game is ended. Ay, 'tis well to keep you men at a distance; Forms in Love, like Mysteries in Religion, make Reason truckle, but advance your Zeal.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Asses, they say, run the faster under a Load. For my part, I am like the Fireship that scorns to burn, till sure to kindle Flames in something worth burning for.

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.p: So that like most of ours you're in no great danger of burning; for the Enemy is not more afraid of▪ em than Women are afraid of Wits, or fond of Beaux.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Beaux! Why, we hear nothing so much rail'd at now as those tame Animals! Pray, what do you properly call a Beau, Mr. Airy?

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.p: A Beau is—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p:
Stay, let me tell that— Why, a Beau is a kind of a two-legg'd thing, that talks, and walks, and dances,
and sings, and dresses, and looks like something between a Man and a Woman, that seldom keeps a secret better than the latter, and strives to outdo 'em in taking care of the outside, conscious there's little within. It rises to go to Bed, is two hours at the Toilette a dressing, dispatching of Duns, and spoiling gilt paper to dispatch it as Billets Doux, sometimes to its sweet self, and all day making Love to its dear Carcass and sweeter Cloths.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Ay, but there are other sorts of Beaux?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Oh, yes; now Beau is every thing: there's your Town, Court, Camp, Sea, Church, and Country Beau. Sometimes Beau is Mr. Smerk with his diminutive Band and powder'd Bob: sometimes Dash a Lawyers Clerk, that pomatum's his Face, washes it with Milk and Water, and is two hours turning up his hair at night, that it may sit in Curls the next morning. There are dirty Beaux, and Beau Footmen too, and old Beaux in abundance! Nay, now a Man's a Beau if he has but a clean Handkercheif.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Methinks 'tis time the Name were abdicated.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: The Name may be laid down, but the thing will continue, as long as Womens Inclinations continue the same.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Nay, if you begin with us, I must put in for the honour of our Sex.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Which is just like the honour of ours, and that's so little I'm asham'd to tell you.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p:
Come, those Wits ought to be fool'd who make their Addresses to Fools; how fine 'tis to see one of you follow some foolish Celia like her Shadow, and go even to St. James's or St. Ann's, for a single look cross a Pew; pelt her with Billets Doux commonly stol'n, Nonsensical, or Romantic, write dull Madrigals on her, and get 'em
sung to duller Tunes at your weekly interviews in York-buildings; and lose his rest for her, while Miss Celia all the while either sleeps or laughs at him.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Ten to one but he has his turn to laugh at her: Look you, Madam, one half of the world first banters the other, then one half of the world lies with the other, and at last one half of the world laughs at the other.

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.p: Therefore I would not have our Sex trust the other.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Not so fast Cousin; I believe of you and Mr. Railmore as I do of both Sexes.

sp.speaker: La. S.
sp.p: What's that, dear Christina?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Why, the one is in the wrong, and the other is not in the right.

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, were the world such as they wou'd both be thought, a married pair wou'd be as great a rarity as—

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: A self-denying Priest, or a couple that never repented after the Hony Moon.

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.p: Have a care, Sir; all people marry at one time or other.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, and repent it at one time or other; look you, when two marry, both part with their Freedom to each other, yet neither of them gets it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: There I agree with you: For my part a Husband's Inconstancy and Ingratitude are no less my aversion than a Wife's lazy subject way of living. I could not waste half my time at my Glass, and the rest on Children, Nurses, and mean houshold affairs; and on a Drunkard, a Gamester, a Debauchee, a jealous Coxcomb, or an ill-natur'd Blockhead, who would look on me only as a means to mend his Fortune, or an Obstacle to his Pleasures.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Nor would I become a property for the sake of a little Dross or fancied Charms, which like a Will in the Wisp vanish when they've deluded us into a Pit whence there's no getting out; then the seeming Angel proves a real Devil, neglects her self for her Fool, and adorns her self only for others.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Oh, say no more; were not you Men to be caught by meer outside as well as we, we should seldom take such care about it, and were you not so blind when caught, we would not be so careless before you afterwards. But let's talk of something else. What if we shou'd sit down yonder.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: With all my heart.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Airy and Kitty.

sp.speaker: Airy
sp.p: This is young Frankly's little Mistress: I've a mind to try how she bears my Friend's absence— Stay dear pretty creature, I must call you to an accoun●●

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: O Laird, Sir! for what?

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.p: Why? for making me love you whether I will or no; such an Air, such Eyes, such blooming Beauty, will make more Men run mad than Poetry, Plotting, or Phanaticism.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Nay, as I hope to be sav'd, Sir, I can't help it. Wou'd you have my Eyes put out?

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.p: Thy Eyes! why, Child, I had rather the Sun were put out. Oh I wou'd still gaze on those dear damn'd bewitching Eyes, and hear that sweet pretty prattling Tongue.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: O Law! the Man's mad indeed!— Yet methinks I like this kind of Madness mightily.

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.p: Why, don't I tell you you'●l make the whole Nation a Bedlam, if 'tis not one already— Nay, you must not go yet.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Why, Sir, you own you are mad, and I should be mad too should I stay with you— Let me go.

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.p: Oh mine's a Madness that will hurt none but my self, dear Creature; come, you must stay, you can never have an opportunity to appear fully beautiful but alone with a Man that loves you.

sp.speaker: Kit
sp.p: If you love me, why don't you let me go? Yet methinks I cou'd stay to grow handsomer.

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.p: I won't let you go, because I love you. Why, you are grown infinitely more charming in an instant.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Ah! why must we dissemble. Methinks 'tis a pretty innocent thing to be talk'd so to!
Well▪ Sir, tho they tell me I'm too young to be courted, I'm old enough to know I'm flatter'd.

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.p: Were you before your Glass you'd find it truth: but a Kiss or two will make you incomparable. Dear lovely Sweetness.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Oh; no, no, no, no; no kissing at all.

div.stage: She sings; he presses till he kisses her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Bless me! he's kissing the Girl, and she refuses it as faintly as if she desir'd he should do more! Aside Kitty, is this what I taught you? 'S death, Sir, you ought to pay dear for this presumption.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Why, Sister, the Gentleman is a very civil Gentleman; he only try'd to make me handsomer.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I think he has done it indeed; he has put a colour in your face. O my word you shall go into a Nunnery speedily.

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, so she shou'd; for she'll be the Torment of both Sexes if she is not lock'd up.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Airy, I did not think you would have taken so much pains with a Girl, while so many Women would have thank'd you for the Office?

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.p: Truly, Madam, Girls have often more Wit than Women, they seldom refuse what they like. And then while you have Mr. Railmore with you, who is a Master in that Profession, why should you grudge your Sister those innocent Improvements which you deny your self.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: He a Master in that Art! he's too surly to have any Scholars.

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.p: And your Ladyship too scornful to be taught. But I suppose 'tis because your Charms admit of no increase, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Oh, your Servant, Sir; no more of this, I pray; I would have my Sister, like me, shun such dangerous Instructions.

lg.l: Love is a Foe by Flight alone subdu'd;
So Daphne gain'd the Lawrel when pursu'd:
The God was fir'd, and own'd and urg'd his Flame;
The Virgin blusht, and fled, and overcame.

div.head: ACT II.
SCENE A Dining Room.
div.stage: Sir Thomas Gaymood, Lord Lovewel, Railmore, Airy, Young Gaymood, Francelia, Christina, and Kitty are discovered ready to rise from Table. Frankly in Maids Cloths and other Servants waiting.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: HEre, take away! Nay, Girls, what need you rise? I've a Dance and some Music for the Company.

div.stage: While the Dance is performing enter Sir Topewel Clownish, and Squire Illbred, who make Antic Gestures, as if they would be dancing too.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: How is't, old Boy? how fares it with thy body? hale and lusty, full of juice, full of gravy, hah?

div.stage: Claps Sir Tho. hard on the Shoulder, and shakes him by the hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Sir Topewel Clownish! Adad stand off▪ or I'll beat thee▪ a Peasecods on thy Shoulder of Mutton Fist; why did not you come to dine with me, old Suckface? I have the rarest Hock now! Many a German Prince gets drunk with worse; and as for Red stuff, here's▪ that would make a divided County vote one and all, by old England! here's to you, old Sot!

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Thank you Brother: Look you, Mum's the word. I'll tell you what 'tis in the twinkling of a Bumper. Here, John, John, do you fill me yonder Beer Glass, only for a Taste, John.

sp.speaker: Sir The.
sp.p: Squire Illbred, I'm glad to see you; you're welcome!

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: The like to you, Sir Thomas! Odsme, I shall ne're be able to break my mind to my Mistress: my Heart beats like any Mill-clapper; 'tis e'n sinking into my Breeches, e ' saith.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Cousin, don't hang on Arse: Odsooks, show your head, Man, and go buss the Women, if thou wou'dst.
But hold, here's to thee: Do nothing rashly, as the saying is, soft and fair, as Lawyers go to heaven, drink first.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: Mistress Frances, your Health: Sir Thomas here's towards you. Tastes, and spurts it out. Humh! 'tis so, so; I think 'tis almost as good as our Stale Beer.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Sir Topewel, thou right worshipful Bumkin, thou glorious Phiz painter, thou walking Cellar of March Beer, and Terror of Sippers and Flinchers, egad I'm as glad to see thee sober in this House, as thou art to see a stranger drunk at thine.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Thank you, Squire Prate-apace.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Egad, old Tough-hide, I'm come to have t' other bout with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why, I've only made some, stay, let me see, ay, ay— No, ay, some ninety nine as drunk as Cuckolds (I mean as Londoners) since I knock'd thee down, and thou'rt come just time enough to make up the hundred.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: I've a couple of Seconds here, you old Toast, they'll stand by me.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Ay, and full by thee too, before I've done with 'em. I don't know 'em: I never know a man till I've drunk with him— Odsooks I had e'en forgot bussing. Cozen, follow; methinks I'm a dancing the New Vagaries.

div.stage: Sings part of that Tune, as he goes to kiss the women, who seem unwilling.

sp.speaker: Fran:
sp.p: Fye, Sir Topewel, since you Men kiss one another like Children, to kiss Women grows out of fashion at London.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Then it's a sign 'tis in fashion in the Country. Odsooks, I had rather kiss a Hog's Snout than slabber a bristly fellow who makes a Hen's Breech at you with his Chaps. I'll warrant, that's outlandish.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: The Booby kisses like a Nurse; here's a Smack as loud as that of a Carriers Whip

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: A Dewse take you and your Dutch Buss! Were you to kiss thus at London, 'twould cost some Women half their outward face.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Foh! you stink of Wine.
sp.stage: To Sir Topewel after he has forc'd a Kiss from her.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Odsooks, you young Sucker, you proud Tit-bit of Flesh for your Children, does Wine stink? give me my Buss again. Bir, bir, bir.

div.stage: She runs from him, and he strives to catch her.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: I'll owe it you, I'll owe it you.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: I've a coming stomach to Kisses, e 'faith! By y'r leave, Miss.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: By yours, Master!

div.stage: He offers to kiss her; she hits him a slap o' the face.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: Thank you; but what's that for, tho?

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Why, that's for you: My Lips are bespoke, but my hand's at your service; d'you want another?

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: No, you young Light-skirts, I have too much by one— Go, munch Oatmeal! What's the Girl afraid of? a Horse Buss? Why, the Parson's Daughters, nay the Justice's Wife, let me smack 'em again and again, and welcome; and there's our Susan saith, I've a breath like a Cow's 'tis so sweet— Well, if the Mistress won't the Maid shall▪ e'faith.

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.p: He's in the right on't; when we can't get into the Town we must e'en take up in the Suburbs.

sp.speaker: Sir The.
sp.p: Now you shall hear a Song set by my Daughter's Music-master.

lg.l: FRom Aberdeen to Edenbrough
I trudg'd it with my Bearn,
And thence to London Town did go,
News of my Love to learn.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Aud now the bonny Lad is come
To Royal Willy here,
So I'se e'en gang contented home▪
Sin I have got my dear, &c.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Pray, how does your Lordship like the composing?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I like it extremely, Madam.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: Oh! is that a Lord!

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Like it! Why, there's not a word of drinking in't. Odsooks one merry Drinking Catch is worth a hundred on't; as, Oh the little House that lies under the Hill! Thrilo, lilo, lilo, lilo, liloh!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Well, here's something will fit you to a Hair.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Redding in a Smith's Habit, a Bottle in his hand. He sings; seemingly drunk.

div.head: SONG.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: SHou'd I not lead a happy Life▪
Were but my Bottle like my Wife!
My Bottle empties when I swill,
But my Wife swells up when we bill.
Wou'd (when I drink) my Bottle fill,
And (when I kiss) my Wife not swell,
That daily gaily I wou'd spend my Life,
My merry Bottle and my Wife.

div.stage: Drinks; then throws away his Bottle, and takes up a Quart Pot.
Enter Mr. Lee drest as the Smith's Wife and big-bellied.

div.head: DIALOGUE.
div.stage: He gives her the Drink, she drinks.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: How sweet! oh how it chears my heart!
O dear! methinks I suck my Mother.
Here's t'you, my Love! have t' other Quart,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: — What then?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Come, now we're Friends, and all is right.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Drink, drink all day, but love at night.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Now this is something like a Tanzy: here Friends, there's a couple of Shillings for you to drink.

sp.speaker: Ch. Fye.
sp.p: Sir Topewel, you affront 'em, and us too; they never sing under a couple of Guineas.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Well then, if they'll come to Clownish-hall they shall be drunk for a month together— Here, John, do thou take up the Shillings, and then fill me t' other Brimmer, you old Cuckold!

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.p: Why, this is treating indeed; let the Ladies but be kind, and there will be Chere Entiere.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Pshau, my little Hotspur, the whole kind will be kind, if we are not too kind. They are like Fruits, Man; if they're dear e'en thank your impatience, you might have enough else for little or nothing in due season; there's plenty and they won't keep; when the Pears are ripe, do He shakes one of the Women but shake the Trees, and down they tumble— What say'st thou of this old grinding Mill, hah!

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p:
Why, I only say, that's old; thou steal'st Trash out of Books, as impudently as Boys do out of Orchards; nay, the worst on't is, that like other Thieves thou
spoil'st what thou steal'st, lest thy Roguery be found out.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Pshau, pshau, a meer Poetic License, by Mercury. The God of Wit is the God of Thieves too. Why, Man, every body steals: the Country Levite steals Sermons, nay the very Invectives he uses against stealing: the younger Brother with his pious Dad's abetting steals a Fortune, the Hypocrite steals a good Name, the common Soldier steals Hens and Geese, the Commander Towns and Countries, and both, like the cozening Citt, call that Getting. The busy ignorant steals a Preferment, and the sly Cuckold-maker steals your Wife.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: And thou thy Speeches.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: I deny the major: I pay for the Books out of which I take 'em, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: We'll take a Walk in your Gardens, Sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: What are they all a going? A Pox of these peticoated Implements; they spoil Company worse than Business, Politics, or Religion. Well, I'll be with you; but first let's smoke a Pipe.

div.stage: Exeunt Ld. Lov. Francelia, Christ. Kitty, Rail, and Airy.
Manent Sir Tho. Sir Top. Illbred, Gaymood, Frankly, and another Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: These seem clever fellows, Squire? hark you, can they drink?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Just as you talk, Knight.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Why, so, so; you only talk to promote drinking, and they only drink to promote talking— Where are they now? They cou'd not say that's stoln! Aside, Now this is lost here; meer Pearl before Swine, by Mercury.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: What say'st thou, hah?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing, I was only thinking o' some of you Country Squires.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Odsooks one Country Fellow of Threescore is worth threescore of your spindle-shankt washy finical Town-whipsters, with scarce a Penny in their Pockets, or any Pith in their Backs, but the Devil and all of Maggots in their Noddles, and of Convent-garden Gout in their Bones.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Can they—

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Brother, not afford against the Country. You Town Changelings arrive froward Children; you're always biting your Nurse: Can you live without the Country?

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Well said, e 'faith. Now look you, Neighbor, here's no body too much: You see my Cousin Illbred▪ Is he not a elever sort of a body, for an elder Brother? Here's a Man now! I'll warrant him as sound Wind and Limb as any he of his inches: Odsheart, he'll wear well and live long!

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Not live, but last long▪ e 'gad, one would swear he were commending his Horse to pack it off to some Fool at a Fair.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: He hunts, hawks, or whistles, about his ground three hours in a morning, feeds like a Plough-jobber, and drinks like a Tinker: As silly as he stands he made 14 Lawyers drunk last Assizes.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: You've a rare Pupil of him.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: In short you have him as true bred a Country-man as my Worship, and wanting nothing but a Wife, by the Pleasure of Drinking: nor shall he want that long, if my Neighbor here is willing to be rid of his eldest Daughter; for that's what we come about.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: My Daughter Francelia! There are more words than one to a Bargain, Sir Topewel, my Friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: An you be not willing to get rid of that Cattle, you're the only Man of your mind in seven Counties. Why, they are meer Rubbish, Father Dry-boots, we must pay those that take 'em away.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Ay, marry, but e'ry Man shan't be the Scavenger. What, I must bestow my Jewel upon a Fool, an Ideot, a Booby, a senseless Clown?

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: Odsbobs, I shall have her, I'll lay five pounds to a Nut Cracker he means me, for every body calls me so.
Thank you, Father-in-law that's to be.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Adad, Sir, you had best keep your Thanks till you have her.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Hark you, Neighbor, Mum's the word. I guess where the Shoo wrings; you grudge to untye your Purse-strings to him, you old Micher; now we want none of your Muck.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Humh! I may save a Portion! Aside Adad that's more than I thought.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Did I not tell you, you old Hunks, that my Cousin wants nothing but a Wife? See how he sniggers at it! how arch the young Whoreson looks! Whee, Man! he's not the Fool you may take him for.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: No more I an't: I'm none of your raking, scraping, sneaking Fools, although I may'nt say so much where I an't acquainted.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Can he be a Fool with three thousand a year, besides eighteen hundred more which shall be his— When they can no longer be mine.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: He's a Wit, he's a Wit; I'll bring 18 Dedicating Poets will draw their Pens to vouch it to the last drop of their Ink, by Mercury: But if that won't do, how d' you think I'll make him a Wit?

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: What you'll beggar him, or you'll—

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: No, stay, I'll tell you my self. First, he shall read half a score Plays, that is, if he can read: then I'll teach him to make Rebus's, Quibbles, Semiquibbles, Quarter-quibbles, Conundrums, Carwitchets, Longinquopetits, Clinches, Puns—

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Heigh day! what's all this?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Do you know what's Cross Purposes, or Questions and Commands.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Why Puns, Carwitchets, & coetera, are not at all like that— But they are all the wit in fashion, and as easily learn'd as Fornication; your very Country Parsons are as capable of it as any Men.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: I'm sure that must needs be easy then: Susan, Sister's Chambermaid, might teach one that in a quarter of an hour.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Then he shall go to every new Play▪ and when he hears a good sharp Kiss, he shall lug out of his Pocket the Terror of Scriblers, that is, a Musical Instrument call'd a Catcall.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: A Catcall!

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Ay, a Catcall egad; with a touch of this▪ I'll blow you a poor Devil off the Stage in a trice, after he has been a whole year drudging on a Farce.

div.stage: He makes a Noise with the Catcall.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: Ods my heart, I fancy I could do this my self.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Look you, he's half a Critic already.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Ay, ay, all in good time: but to the point. What say you Sir Thomas?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I must confess you bid fair, but I have given my Lord Lovewell leave to court her; and then, who knows whether she may fancy the Squire?

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: I'm sure she'll soon like him, he's so good natur'd a Lad▪ he has a Lord's Estate, and prithee what's a Title? why, you can no more know some young Lords now from Citizens Heirs, than most of us from Graziers; then they're somewhat apt to outrun the Constable they say.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: But my Lord's none of those, and loves her well.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Ay, now perhaps: but hark you me, when did you hear of a Lord that lov'd his Wife six weeks together? Here, John; where's John? Come Sweet-heart To Frankly fill me a Streaker of Wine.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Well, you have my leave, Mr. Illbred▪ and I'll do what I can to prevail with my Daughter. I fancy you had best send her a Letter, and come an hour or two after.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: So he shall; we're a going to Mother Hemp's, he shall write it there, and send it anon—. Here, Huzzy, fill as you love me; fill as 'twere for thy self, and no body by: Odsooks, fill it full! What's the Brim made for else?
sp.stage: Nods to Sir Thomas, and drinks.
sp.p: Well, Sir Thomas, God be with you.

div.stage: Shakes him hard, and claps him on the back.

sp.speaker: Illb▪
sp.p: God by t'you, Sir Thomas! My Love to your Daughter! I long mightily to he in with her. Thank you for your good Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho
sp.p: I'll see you out, and then I'll go look for her?

div.stage: Exeunt Sir Tho. Sir Top. Squire Illbred, and Frankly.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: And I for Railmore, to tell him what hopeful Bargain's a▪ driving to put my Lord's N●●● out of joy▪ nt▪ then heigh for a juicy Country Lass! I'm for easy work ●ga●; and I fancy she that waited now might do; she's somewhat raw that's the truth on't: but we're in the Country, where a kind Wench is as scarce as a sound one in Covent-garden: she may mend there like others formerly of no higher rank.
Some, not far off, as ill became their Cloaths,
Who now set up for Settlement and Beaux.

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE A Room.
div.stage: Enter Gaymood on one side, Frankly on the other.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: OH! here's the Game! what a buxom Bona Roba she'll make! Well, I may safely venture I hope; yet I have heard of a Town Spark who made a Token of his Kindness go round a whole Country Parish. My young Master pepper'd the Dairy-maid, the Dairy-maid peppered the Groom, the Groom peppered the Chamber-maid, the Chamber-maid peppered his Worship, his Worship peppered my Lady, my Lady peppered the Parson, and the Parson's Wife peppered my young Master again! And what a circulation of blood was there! aside. To Frankly. Hark you, Child, come hither; come, dont be bashful, that grows out of fashion now as much as honesty. She blushes; that's a wonder! I thought nothing but Spanish Wool could make Women red now a days! what's thy Name, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Frances Pinngown, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: How long hast thou liv'd here, Child?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But two days, Sir: I came upon liking, and am to go to morrow. I found they were turning me away, so I was resolv'd I would not stay.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Gad those that don't like thee must be more difficult than I.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: There's a deal of Linnen to be washt, and I an't si● for that work.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Hark you, come and live with me, do; I've work thou'rt sit for; then there will be but little washing, for I wear a Shirt a fortnight.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Maids must not live with single Gentlemen, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Pshau, pshau, that's a mistake, Child. Come, if thou can'st but make a Bed I'll teach thee to unmake it: A days thou shalt be my Maid, but my Mistress a nights, according to the laudable Custom of City Widowers and Batchelors.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Oh! sye, Sir!

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Come and live with me, I say, thou'lt live like a little Queen.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir, I dare not; I have learnt to know better things: then who'd be so foolish d'you think, as to hearken to one whom his elder Brother talks of marrying out of hand?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Why, Child, he may talk on't, but I mind him as little as most Daughters do their Mothers: but suppose I should marry 'twill be the better for thee; for I'll no sooner have finger'd my Wise's Portion, but I furnish thee stately Lodgings in some creditable House, at least a Churchwarden's or a Head Constable's; keep thee a Footman and a gilt Chariot, and make thee outshine a Lord's public Mistress, or a Bankers private Friend.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Let me go Sir— You must not— let me alone▪ I can't do as you'd have me— Pish! You shall never make a Harlot of me. Oh fie, Sir! some body sees you.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: What need you care? you are not to stay.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Not with you if I wou'd prosper.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Fool! what way have Chambermaids to prosper but that?

div.stage: Enter Sir Thomas Gaymood and Francelia▪

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Come▪ Girls, now I have thee aside, let me ask thee a question; what think'st thou of a Husband, hah?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: As most Wome do, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fran
sp.p: Which is as good as to say thou always think'st of it, hah?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I mean, Sir, I think 'tis dangerous venturing on one

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Ay, and more dangerous being without one. Why▪ 'tis as bad as having arable Land lye fallow— In short I have agreed to marry thee speedily.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Sir, there needs no haste; I'm not weary of my condition.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: But thy Father's weary of seeing thee so long courted tho; besides I fancy a Husband is a kind of a pretty play thing for a Child of thy size, heh!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My Lord has spoke to him I find.
You are resolved, Sir, to put me to the Blush.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: So, she smiles, I think. Adad, these women can as little hide their Joy before Marriage, as we our Sorrow afterwards— Well, silence gives consent. It must and shall be so.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I must like what you like, Sir; and would even sacrifice my inclinations to your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Thou'rt my good Girl! Well, I have settled matters to my mind, and thou shalt be a Bride to morrow.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: 'Tis very sudden, Sir, but you're absolute.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Look you, you'll have a Letter from him just now; and he'll come and pay you a Visit an hour after. 'Tis Squire Illbred: Oh he'll make a rare Husband!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Illbred! my mistake has undone me.

sp.speaker: Sir Th.
sp.p: Prithee what makes thee look so odly of a sudden?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I am thinking, Sir, that Marriage brings many cares.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Prithee, what cares can Wives have, while their Husbands live, unless it be how to cuckold them? Come leave this dissembling.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But indeed, Sir, I do not dissemble.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p:
Humh! Now I understand you: You don't mislike Marriage, Mistress, but the Man you should marry.
He mimicks her. I must like what you like, Sir; and wou'd even sacrifice my inclinations to your pleasure! hah! is't come to that?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I must confess, I fear I should live unhappy with such a Man: I'm afraid he is a Fool.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What then? will he make ever the worse Husband?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: A meer Clown!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Prithee, who but Clowns love their Wives now a days?— Look you, don't provoke me: you know my humour that's enough: as for my Lord, as he came, so let him go; he wants Money, now the Squire wants none. Come along, come along.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: What pity 'tis I wa'n't bred a Scholard! I fancys I'd ha' made as good a Man as our Parson▪ I ha'n't forgot one word of my Message: I'll say't now as if Meester's Sweet-heart was by▪ He moves his Hat, and bows awkardly. Forsooth▪ Squire Illbred remembers his kind Love to you, and has sent you a Letter.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Odsnigs▪ here's my Jade Doll that I lov'd so once, till she took out John the Thresher to dance! I'd as leive ha' met a mad Cow in a narrow Lane.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: What d' you want hah?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: I don't want you, goody Trollop, I want to come at your betters.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: Marry, come up, Looby! I'll know why you come creeping like a Dog under a door for all your haste? You come at my betters? I think you're afore your betters now.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Come, help me to thy Dame's Speech an' thee w●●d▪ st; then go thy ways to John the Thresher, like a sorry hollow hearted dirty Slut as thee art.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: I care n't an he were hang'd, and you too.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: What does this fellow want?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: An't please you, forsooth; an't please you, my Meester— Aside. Oh the sight of this Jade has daunted me so, I don't know what I say or do; I've quite and clean forgot my Errand— I have a Letter forsooth Searches for it Odsnigs, either I forgot my self, or Meester forgot his self— I'm come away without it— No, stay, I took it of the Parson. I'll look again. Marry▪ I lost it— No, marry, but I han't— Ay, marry, I have— No marry but I han't— Here 'tis; Gives it her. Meester gave me strict charge to give it Sir Thomas's handsomest Daughter, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: We seldom think others handsomer than our selves— Let see— 'Tis for my Sister; but dear Curiosity, Woman's favourite Vice, cannot be withstood— I'll open it— heigh day! what stuffs this? o'th my word the Parson's unlawful Issue tho the Booby Squire fathers it.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: An you'll send an answer by me, forsooth▪ I'll deliver it safe to Meester (I can deliver a Message passing well, you see) Else he bade me tell you, he'll come for▪ t anon, he's somewhat busy at present.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Why, if you must know, forsooth, I left him hard at it, smoaking his Pipe yonder at Mother Humps.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Nay▪ then he's busy indeed; stay, I'll bring you an answer presently.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Well, and what business had you to stand and state in a body's face, and put a body out? I ne're was half so sham'd in my born days, not I.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: What did you cast a Sheep's Eye at me for?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Because I was a Fool I think. O' my Conscience you're nothing in the varsal world but mischief: But if e're I set Eyes on thee again while I have breath to draw, may the Crows come and peck 'em out!

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: And so say I: Goodb'y t'ye.

div.stage: Going, casts a look at him.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: What dost look at me so for?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: What d'you look on me for?

div.stage: Weeps, and wipes her Eyes with her Apron.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: What dost thou cry for? Oh▪ 'tis a peerless Jade!

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Oh that I should live to be us'd thus!

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Why did you serve me so then with that sneaking Whelp John the Thresher, who's no more to compare d' you see (thof I say't, that shou'd not say't) than a Hog's to a Bullock▪— You know I would ha' broken Silver with you once, but that the plaguy Collectors had not left one broad Shilling in the County.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: I only took him out to try thee, Humphry.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd then, and my Horse too.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Nay, prithee don't pout, Humphry; don't spoil that sweet face of thine: if I e're do so again, may I' be churning and churning all days o' my Life, and Butter ne're come.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Ay, marry, hang you; I'll trust you no further than I can hurl you.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Don't be dumpish, Humphry, I'll dance with you now; we've Minstrels hard by.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Not I, e'en dance with somebody else, and thou woud'st.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Well then I will, Humphry; any thing to please poor Humphry Doddipole.

div.stage: Exit. and Re-enters with Fidlers, Country Lads and Lasses.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Oh that John the Thresher sticks plaguily in my Gizzard still.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Oh brave Doll. Hoydon! That wag of the Buttock has won my heart.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: Be quiet! Aloud, seeing Christina— Here's Mistress Aside to him. Can't you let a body alone?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I find every body has his own little private business in this world! Aside. Here, fellow, give thy Master this.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: I will, forsooth: This is a lucky day. Ods me, I warrant this good News will renew Father's Lease for nothing.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Mr. Railmore, just now this thing▪ in the shape of a Letter, was sent by my Lord's new Rival, the Squire you saw here. I was taken for my Sister, and as the hates him, and I have a respect for your Friend, I sent a short drolling answer, in her Name, as kind as a Billet Doux writ by a Town Beau to himself.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: I hope he'll make it as public, be as little believ'd and worse us'd: Look you, Madam, you do well; 'tis your interest to disappoint the Squire; for, after all, were my Lord dismist, I guess you must stay for a Husband as long as she'll be teaz'd with such Fools. Be generous then as all the world is, and be thank'd for obliging your self; but you must do more.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Write two or three Lines as from your Sister to my Lord, as it were to assure him, that tho she weds the Squire she'll favor his Lordship ne're the less. I'll take care the Uncle and the Nephew shall see it instantly. I've already set some other Engines at work?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: But what if my Sister hears of this? I'm sure she'll not only disown it utterly; but will hardly forgive my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: He must know nothing of it himself, till it has taken▪ Effect▪ then we'll easily reconcile 'em, if she hears on't, and, like other Women, seems angry for being pleas'd.

lg.l: None can a Good, th● got by Tricks, disdain,
When others reap the Blame, and she the Gain.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I ha'n't had an Opporunity to ask you, Why you're so Melancholy, Madam? I love you better than any Body, so nothing could please me more than to see you chearful.

sp.speaker: Kitt.
sp.p: Thank you, good Fanny, but you can't make me so.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You may be mistaken, Madam; come, do but discover the Cause of your Sadness to me, and if I don't serve you effectually, may I never deserve a Lady's good Opinion!

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: What wou'd you have me say? I protest I don't know why I'm so▪

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Oh! that's a Jest; but we Maids are so bashful! Come, I fancy, your Secret will out the more kindly, if I ask you a few Questions. Are you not in Love? Nay, I my self would be one of the first to laugh at you▪ if you did not know what 'tis to love.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: Well▪ don't laugh at me, good Fanny, I know what 'tis well enough, but my Sister must not know of it for the World.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Good! I like you now▪ Plain dealing becomes us Maids, when we're among our selves no less than Dissimulation before Men: Come then, be free, and believe I'll keep your Secret as well as your Lover himself.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: But why don't you ask me Questions then, Fenny, that I may answer you?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: That's well said! you love some young Gentleman, do you not?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: When I was at London, there us'd to come with my Cousin Will Gaymood a pretty fine drest▪ Gentleman, who came from the College; his Name's Mr. Frankly.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And do you love him very well?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: I lov'd him mightily then▪ but I did not tell him so; for, they say, We must not tell Men our Mind till they find it out; yet I fancy he guest it; for, he promis'd me he wou'd come, or let me hear from him: But he has not done it. Now as my Sister threatens me with a Nunnery—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Pray go on, I'm impatient, to know the rest.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: I am asham'd; I had rather you wou'd ask▪ me Questions▪ Fanny.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I fear you've got a new Lover in his Absence.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: I vow, I could not help it, Fanny▪ But▪ I'm mightily concern'd, and don't know what to do; for he is to come to me by and by, and I am afraid my Sister shou'd see him with me. Now, if thou woudst help me a little, good Fanny.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I had rather serve t'other; but what's this new one's Name?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: Major Buff; I like him but so so; but he teez'd me, and would not let me alone till I had promis'd to meet him; and any thing is better than a▪ Nunnery, you know. Yet I would not have talk'd to him had Mr. Frankly come to me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: The Absent are always in the Wrong, I find.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: But, Fanny, there's Doctor Kill-●lown too▪ whom I promis'd to meet▪ and I'm mightily afraid they'll come at the same Time.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Another Appointment! a forward Child, truly! But why did▪ you appoint him at the same Time?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: What shall I say to you? I did not think on't: I'm so concern'd for Mr. Frankly's not coming, and so afraid of the Nunnery, that I don't know what I do▪ But as I grow older I hope I shall manage things better▪ and have more Wit▪

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: More Wit▪ why you're a Prodigy already! But, what if Mr. Frankly shou'd come at last? For, I am sure he'll come, since he promis'd▪ I know him.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: Oh! let me kiss thee again and again for that dear, dear Fanny kisses Frankly▪ Well is he not a pretty sweet Man? Methinks he favours thee mightily.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: He's well enough▪ I think▪ But▪ wou'd you marry him if he cou'd get you out in Page's Cloaths, and had a Parson ready?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: Heh! truly, I know nothing to the contrary, Fanny. Yet there's another pretty fine Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Another yet!

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.p: That's all indeed▪ Fanny▪ One Mr. Airy: I'm sure you would like him, Fanny: But yet dear Mr. Frankly was my first Love, and if I were but as sure he wou'd come—

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: As you are sure of a Kiss.

div.stage: Kitty and Franly shriek and exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: You have lost her, and I my little Chamber-Utensil: Well▪ no matter for that▪ I've had her already▪ B●●, tho she seems so skittish now▪ I gad, true Modesty is as great a Stranger to these Chambermaids▪ as to a Midwife▪ a Hedge-Poet, or a Side-Box Mask, by Mercury.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Well, let's go find out Railmore: You say you'll serve my Lord, Sam, and help us to defeat the Squire his new Rival.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Fear not, I'll do't, tho 'twere but to fret my covetous old Brother, be reveng'd of the Unkle, and laugh at the Nephew: I long to do some good generous Action worthy being Chronicled. This shall be the first, Egad; and if the Fool shou'd marry my Neice, to make it more meritorious, I'd drink him dead in Three Months. What a Pox▪ do you think I've no Conscience? I shall save nothing by old Thomas's saving a Portion, and Nephew for Nephew, I'd rather have a witty Lord than a foolish Squire, by Mercury.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: A Pox of all such Men of Clay and no Sense! They are the Terror of those who want only to be marry'd to raise Portions and pay Debts. Women shou'd be oblig'd not to use such rich Fools better than if they had Merit and nothing else: But then

lg.l: How many Heirs wou'd sue, while none wou'd grant!
How many Nymphs wou'd their best Bubbles want!

div.trailer: The End of the Third ACT.

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE A Walk.
div.stage: Enter Gaymood, with Airy; and Christina, meeting.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: HOw now, Mad Cap, whither so fast?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Not to look for you, my Wise Unkle, you may be sure. I'm looking for my Lady Single: Do you know which way she went?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Look you, you know the Passage that leads to the Stairs that are on the Right-Hand, near the Back Yard, as you go up to the Gallery, don't you?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Ay, ay, What then?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Why, she did not go that way— that's all laughs you did not look for that neither, Ha▪ ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Dear Unkle, will you never leave this Folly?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Child, when it leaves me, and thou thy self art wiser: Come, like to like; stay with us, and be Company; hang thinking! Too much Reflexion is the Folly of the Learned.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Ay, and too little Reflexion the Folly of the Ignorant.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Ignorant! Why, I don't trouble my self with what's past or what's to come. I enjoy the present▪ and let the World rub, and who wiser than Sam?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: You do well to praise your self, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Ay, seeing no Body will do it for me, Madam▪ Pshau, 'tis the Fashion now: Shew me the Man that never talk'd ill of others, nor well of himself, and I'll be bound to shew thee a Plain-dealing Courtier, a Peace-making Lawyer, a silent Woman▪ an honest Taylor▪ a witty Alderman, a—

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: A what?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Nay▪ Faith, I can't tell what: Help me out if you can▪

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Why, you are never out nor in▪ Man: Neither will you give me leave to put in a Word, or be happy in exchanging a Speech or two with this Lady.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Nay, now I think on't, thou hast not had thy share of Talk, this one Time: Well, make thy self amends, if thou canst: Come, let me see you box about a little amorous Non-sense; for 'tis what you would be at▪

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Can a Man talk of any thing but Love▪ when there's so strong an Incentive to it before him?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Why, Unkle, would you have me be a Courting-Stock?

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: You need not, Madam, if you're willing to be in earnest.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: That would not be fair, Mr. Airy, for I fancy Love it self is a Jest.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Then give me Leave to pass that Jest upon you; there can be no harm in a little Jesting.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: I'm not much inclin'd to find Fault with a Jest, provided it be not carried too far.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: What think you of Platoni● Love?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: That's a Jest indeed, but 'tis a dull one.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Shall I court you like an eldest Son, sold by his Father to redeem a Mortgage?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: That Courtship is indeed much in fashion, but there's no Jest in it.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Shall I court you then like some first-rate Spark, between a Rake and a Beau; a pleasant modern Medly, like Punch; for there's the strong and the insipid, with the sweet and the sharp?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: That will go down better than the rest, but 'tis a dangerous Mixture, and not fit for common use: However, I'll venture on a Taste to try your Skill.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: By the Blessing of Freedom, I'll stay on the Stage, and will see that Scene for nothing.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: I bar that, Sir, No Person to stand on the Stage.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: The Play-Bill says so, but we'll suppose 'tis the Poet's Day; besides▪ we Beaux will show our selves to the Audience, in spight of the Bill and the Audience.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Ay, tho some of you are as dirty▪ Beaux as your self.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Egad, I'll clap that Jest, he claps We Wits and Beaux love to be satiriz'd in a Prologue; but if you don't begin, now 'tis over, I'll kiss.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Well, Madam, suppose me one of those Sparks just coming to see you, and your self one of those airy Women of Honour they court en passant.

div.stage: Gaymood and Christina sit, Airy comes forwards, seemingly fuddled; humming a Song and combing his Wig; then stops and speaks as to a Servant.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Solyman, speaks affectedly and in another Tone Tell the Coachman I won't discharge him these eight Hours, let the Dog drive away and lose his Fare, if he will— Demme, Madam, you're a very happy Person; you don't know, perhaps, that I've been peeping into every Coach in the Park for you, ferretting the Boxes at both Houses, refus'd to go to Le Begue's with Three or Four Rakes of Honour, balk'd poor my Lady Love-all, who stay'd for me to hand her out of the King's Box, and Two Masks, who waited for me by the Chocolate-house; I'm sure they're Quality; and at last I've been forc'd to drive hither. Confound me, if I did not break the Coachman's Head for his Fare, because the Rascal did not keep a Lover's Pace.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Oh your Servant speaking affectedly sweet Mr. Airy; I easily believe you've been Side-Glassing in the Park, Side-boxing at the Play-House, Acting in the Pit, nay on the Stage too, but no more for me, I dare swear, than for any Human Thing in Petticoats. Some little forgetful Mask has disappointed the no less forgetful Mr. Airy, and I may thank her for this Visit.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: No, demme, Madam, I begin to leave off Masks; they are grown doubly dangerous of late. Sits down in an odd careless Posture But, pray, why han't you a Couch here▪

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: A Couch! Bless me! A Couch! What for?

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Is that a Question to be ask'd a Gentleman? why, for many Uses, my Dear▪ tho 'twere but to loll on.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Spoken en Gallant Homme, as I'm a Christian; respectful and civil to amazement! Hark you, Spark▪ are you still as mad as you us'd to be?

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: I was just going to ask you the same Question. But hark you, han't I forgot to tell you how damnably I love you?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Love me! Bless me! how abruptly you expose a Declaration of Love! This is the first happy Moment I ever heard of it, as I'm a Christian.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Yet I'm confoundedly in Love with you to Day. But we young Fellows are all so full of Mercury, and one Thought drives out another—

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Just as one Mistress drives out another.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: No, I'm a Dog if I don't think I shall love you, even after▪ I am dead. There's something in you so janty, so j●-n●-s●ay-quoyish! Tho methinks you look worse to Day than ever I saw you look in my Life! Why don't you lay on a little more Red? Stay, is that your Hair or a Tour?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: O good Mr. Whatd'you call, for Gad-sake don't look upon me to Day; I'm not a Creature: I should have kept my Bed, as Sir Finical Self-love does, to rest my Features: I've been so sick these Two Nights, that instead of causing a Love without Remedy, I'm a meer Remedy for Love.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: 's Blood, Madam, what what d'you mean to speak thus of the finest Woman▪ in England, and my Mistress too? I'm only afraid you're fallen in love with some starch'd Fop, in Love with no Body but himself. Well, Woe be to him when I know him! I'll do his Business: Demme, I hate a Fop.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: What, are you jealous?

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Oh, like a Devil, 'tis the best Quality I have.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: 'Tis true, a Dose of Jealousie rouses up your sleepy Passion, just for the▪ World, as a Pinch of Snuff revives the Senses: But the Remedy loses its effect when often us'd.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Gad you're witty▪ Never let her be your Wife. sings. Now you talk of Snuff, do you take any? Here's the best plain Dust ever came from Sevil! I begin to leave it off; I take but Twice or Thrice this little Box full every Day— Look on the Inside, 'tis prettily painted.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: O hideous! I look on your filthy obscene Box! I would not touch it for the World.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Look you, 'tis to shew you I love to be free and sans facon. When shall you and I dine at Pontac's or the Rummer?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Ruder than Rudeness it self! what, talk of Taverns to a Woman of Condition, Monster!

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Pshau▪ I go there every Day, with Twenty that are as Nice as your Ladiship. Let's see that Indian Fan, I fancy it turns two ways, and has as pretty Figures on the Inside as my Box.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: You shall no more see it than I wou'd your Box: Fans are as useful to us for Action, and when we've nothing to say, as your Boxes are to you. Fie, Gallanting of Fans is as much out of Fashion as Gallantry.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: But not tearing of 'em, to get you to some Indian House, on pretence to give you better. Throl lollolol!

div.stage: hums a Song, and tears the Fan.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: What, I suppose you've a Mind I should ask you to Sing?

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Why the Devil don't you then? Gad, I fancy you are as fond of being ask'd as I. Why, you sing almost as well as I do. Come, let's sing the last Dialogue our Master set.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Hark you, Madam, can't I move you?
why the Devil do you run?
Ha'n't I told you twice I love you?
come then, kiss me, or I'm gone.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Foh! I hate a Rakish Lover,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: From the Countess to the Cit,
to do at on this Woman's Eyes!

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Yet not one dares be so free,
tho they let me win at Play.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sure we Rakes can better move you;
see this Shape and Leg, my Dear!
In one Minute more I'll love you
than those Fops can in a Year.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: But your Love will soon be over.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Then you'll get a fresher Lover.
Come, to Bed! I long t'embrace.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: First the Hand, and then the Face,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: 's Death, I've a good mind to beat you;
No; to vex you more, I'llgo.
Thus I puff you— I'll go say,
I refus'd your Love to Day.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Then I'll say how I did treat you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: None will believe you cou'd do so.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: All will believe I us'd you so.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Pretty well, pretty well, all but that damn'd Slap on the Face— Well, I shall run mad for you in Two Days, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Poor Mr. Airy! what, gone so far of a sudden?

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: 'Tis the Fashion now: What, wou'd you have me court like a formal Cit, or freeze you with dull whining Stuff, and die in Simile like a meer Beau? We brisk Fellows push on in Love as in War, egad. Towns must quickly yield or be insulted with Bombs, that ruine them as Slander does Reputation, Demme.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: O fie! the intolerable Presumption of Fellows! Had not you better make the Campaign in Flanders than in Pelmel and at the Wells and Bath?

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Pox, I play'd away my Equipage-Mony at Piquet, and that damn'd Bassette— But tell me, dear Creature, how long must I still sigh in vain for you?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Exceeding Pretty, as I'm a Christian! Why, you have not begun yet, that I know of.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: What a Pox, do you reckon this Visit nothing?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: When you can be constant, perhaps I may think you deserve Encouragement.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: 's Death, at that rate I might wait long enough, Child! I find I must storm the Out-works, in order to a General Assault— Thus then I invest the Town, my fair Enemy.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Nay then 'tis Time to call for Relief— Who's there? Unkle! What were you asleep?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: You may swear it, or how▪ cou'd I have been so long without talking? Pox, this Wine is got into my Head! Well, what's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: When a Woman begins to cry out, you may believe the Jest is over.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Why, 'twas but just going to begin.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: I find we've jested too long, I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: I fear I have, for I must follow you in earnest.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Jest or Earnest, 'tis all one to Sam: If he's caught let him take it for his Pains: They say there's no fooling with the Devil, but I fancy that Saying will hardly hold good of Women, Egad.

lg.l: Bewitching Woman's a resistless Evil,
The Devil fools us, but she'd fool the Devil.

div.stage: Enter Railmore, seemingly drunk, Sir Tope, and Ilbred, with his Sleeves tuck'd up, as from the Club

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Nay, since you've got your Load elsewhere, and won't stay, prethee tell us here, in good sober Sense?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Then, in no sober Sense, if this Nephew of thine has her, he'll be a Cuckold; 'twou'd be a Shame if he were not, he has the best Qualifications for't, and wants that to be in the Fashion.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Heighday! I'll warrant you then, your Londoners have brought up that Fashion, these dead Times, for want of Trade; a Cuckold!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Ay, or a Husband, that's all one, I think: Look you, you Put, I'll stand to what I say. reeling, flings down a Letter, the Squire takes it up Canst thou read Squire? Here's a Letter, I took it up by Chance; from whom and to whom d'you think it is, hah?

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Ods me, 'tis from Francelia! 'Tis the same Hand as mine: Let see— he reads scurvily My dear Lord, tho your Francelia is condemned to marry a Fool— (that's me) you may help her to revenge on him the Wrong that's done you— In spight of all slavish Bonds, she vows to be my Lord Lovewel's while she is Francelia— Ods bobs! who'd ha' thought it?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: May the Curse of small Beer, in an Evening light on me, if I don't go and rattle her to some Tune anon!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Hang her, Man! ne're go to her, 'twill spight her more: Besides, my Lord is a bloody-minded Devil, he makes no more of killing a Man than a Doctor of Physic does.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Odsooks, 'tis all a Case, I'll go— but I'll consider on't first.

sp.speaker: Ma.
