sp.p: Odsbobs, Sirs, why d'you leave us so? you're Three Bumpers behind-hand. There's Justice Dolt swears at you like any Carrier in a Slough. Come, Master of mine, come in; don't stand here holding of a Parley.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Not I; I am not such a Sot; I have enough: I'd as soon go to a County-Feast, or a Punning Club at London.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Why, there are not so many Fools here as at London, Friend of mine!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: There are fewer Fools here indeed, because there are fewer People.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Odsbobs, that Shan't serve turn, you shall drink with us for all that.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I'd sooner go back to London among the Rable for, there tolerable Wine at least is had, in good Rooms, if not in good Company; but here your Room is wretched, your Liquor bad, and your Company abominable; and so farewel, Brother Sots.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Well, go thy waies, Nutmeggrater! what pity 'tis, Major Buff, that such a tart witty Knave can't drink!

div.stage: Enter Plot, drest like a Gipsie. Two or Three Gipsies.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I tell you your Fortune, you pretty Man; you live well, you be good Fortune.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: What Vermin ha'we here? Gipsies! nay then mind your Pockets.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: An angry one, an angry one!

sp.speaker: Il,
sp.p: Gad, Unkle, they shall tell me my Fortune, for all that, but I'll mind 'em.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Ay, presently; cross you my Hand with one piece of Silver, I tell you all then.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Here 'tis, old Egypt!

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Let me see your Head! Oh the good strong Head, fit for the Country Justice!

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: What! tell a Man's Fortune by his Head?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Yes, we tell the Lawyer the Fortune by both the Hands, the pretty Woman by the Eye, the Lover by the long Nose, the Drunkard by the Copper-Nose, the Dancing-Master by the Foot, the Taylor by the Calves of the Leg, the Alderman by the Forehead, and you by the whole Head together.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Why, what dost thou take me for then?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Let see! You no be the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: How! no Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: No, but you be the Squire.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Oh ho! well, I'll try your Skill e'Faith. Come, when wan't I well last, hah?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: You have not been well lately.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Now thou'rt a greater Lyar than Patridge's Almanack.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: No, I ben't, I see by your Hand that 'twas— the Itch.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: The Itch! Thou lyest like the Devil's Tooth-Drawer.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I mean the Itch of Love. You be troubled with it yet. You love the very fine Woman, but you be jealous of her, and will not have her for fear—

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Hum! if thou canst but tell me how old I am, I'll believe thou knowest whether she wou'd be honest or no.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Let me see your Mouth! How old was you when your Father Dy'd?

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Sixteen.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Don't stir! and 'tis now since he dy'd.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Five Years.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p:
Look you, I find that if you marry this Woman
that you design to court to Day, you be one very great Cuckold by some great Person; but if you not go to her, and take no notice at all, you soon will have another more to your Mind, with great deal Mony; but this is not to bring you one Cross: And for a Proof of this, I will tell you your Age as you ask me— You be— you be— just One and twenty, as I find by your Mouth.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: stops Plot, Ilbred and Major Buff run after the

sp.speaker: Gipsies.
sp.p: The Gipsies steal off, having first pick'd Ilbred ' s Pockets and Sir Topewel ' s.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Odsooks, the Gipsies ha' pick'd my Pocket— stop 'em, I have one fast— Ah Rogues! You tell Fortunes, but cou'd not tell your own. You shall be trust up next Assizes, hang'd in Chains, and shewn for a right Egyptian Mummy.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Good Sir, hear me! As I'm an honest Man, 'twas not I pickt your Pocket; besides, I'm no Gypsie, an't please you. Oh! Good your Worship, let me go; I'll discover a Plot to you.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: A Plot! no more Plots, we've had too many already.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: 'Tis a Plot against Squire Ilbred to fool him out of his Mistress.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Fool me! The best Lord in the Land make a Fool of me, I won't marry.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: The Devil helps these same Gypsies, they were too nimble for us.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Nay, now I smell a Rat; well, speak Truth and thou shalt go free.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p:
I am my Lord Lovewel's Man, Sir, set on by Mr. Railmore, who e'en now, pretending to be drunk, got you out, and kept you a talking till he saw us, to give me an Opportunity to make the Squire believe he'll be a Cuckold if he marries Mrs. Francelia: He was to
shew you a Letter; that's a sham-one, upon my Honour▪ as well as that the Squire receiv'd.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Why, this was no Sham-Plot tho; this was a Plot indeed: Well, I set thee free for this Discovery; but canst thou not tell me more?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: I shall be turn'd away, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Come, fear not; we'll provide for thee.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Well, you are such good natur'd Gentlemen that it goes against my Heart to see you deceiv'd. I will tell you, whatever comes on't.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: I'll reward thee to thy own Content; believe me, I am no Courtier.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: You must know, my Lord is to marry Mrs. Francelia very privately to Night; not that she hates the Squire, but because my Lord is a Lord, I think: I know no other Reason; for I know some Women that have staid Twelve Years for a Lord, and now wou'd be glad to take up with a Squire, or any thing. Now I fancy▪ I could put your Worship in a way to put his Nose out of Joint, but—

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Come, but me no Buts! serve him, and I'll do thy Business; thy Lord himself shan't live better than thou shalt. Cousin, give him some of the Broad Pieces thou hast for a Taste.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Odsme! they're all Gipsied away: My Pocket has been gutted already. Well, till anon, take this Ring, and that Tobacco Box.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Pray excuse me, Sir; I hate to take any thing for doing good— won't this look like a Bribe?— These real Gipsies, whom I got to come with me▪ could not forbear stealing— Your Worship's most humble Servant— Well, I believe I might easily convey you, when 'tis dark, into the Room by the Hall, where my Lord intends to be married to your Mistress, unknown to any Body but my self and the Chaplain; there won't be so much as a Light, and they are to whisper all the while, for fear Sir Thomas should come and spoil all.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: O rare! We'll come, we'll come.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: 'Twill be dark about an Hour hence, Sir, I'll wait for you near the Hall, but then you must be very private: Your Worship's most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Now, Lads, let's go Drink!

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Here they are!

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: A Word with you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Make haste then, for we're a dry.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: I hear, you raise your Pretences to a Lady, whom I Court with her Father's Consent.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Ay, and he shall Wed her, and Bed her with my Consent, and her Father's Consent. Do you come to be Invited to the Wedding?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: No, we come to forbid the Ba●es, Sir, and to desire you to desist.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: But what if I wont, Sir?

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Then I must try to make you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: So, here's like to be otherguess fighting than we have on our Muster-Days: I'll go get a Reinforcement, and then boldly march up— in the Reer of it.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: You wear a Sword, Sir!

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis but a Hanger neither. Look you, I a'n't for Single Rapier; we scorn your little Spit-frog Play: That's a French Trick: But for Wrestling, Cudgels, or good downright Backsword slashing, may haps I won't turn my Back to the best Master of the Science in the County.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Why, that's only fit for Butchers and Hedge-Fencers, to fight sham Prizes before a Bear-Garden Rabble.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: I'll Drink with you for her then, and Unkle will be my Second.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Sir, if you wou'd show yourself a Gentleman, get a Sword and—

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: My Bay Gelding shall run▪ with the best Horse in your Stable for her, three Heats, Weight him and Inch him— Methinks I shou'd not want Courage, I drink Stout and Cherry-Brandy e'ry Day.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Odssooks, say no more, Cuz, Lug out, we'll make their hollow Blades fly in shatters about their Coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Say you so, Sir? Then have at yours.

div.stage: They draw and fight: Sir Top▪ and▪ Ilb▪ give way till the Clowns come, then they come forward, and are, by a Mistake, knock'd down by their Party, and crawl off: The Clowns are beaten off the Stage.
Enter Humphrey and two Clowns with Flails and Quarter-staffs, Major Buff behind 'em, Hallowing, and Parson Humdrum while they are fighting.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Odsnigs, Thrash 'em thick and threefold; have among you blind Harpers, fall Back fall Edge.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Gentlemen, Pax▪ est bona res, says a Learned Father; Peace is a good Thing: Knock 'em down, Humphrey, Peace is a good Thing: Knock 'em down, Humphrey.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Come, my Lord, we've got the Day, as most Generals do, by Chance▪ You'll scarce be made one, tho' we shou'd win t'other Battle; so, let's away to think of other means to defeat your Rival effectually; for, after all, he's but the more dangerous for being a Blockhead.

div.stage: Enter Lady Single; with a Book in her Hand; her Woman at a Distance.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Oh, why do we complain we live too little! When ev'n the Wise want something more than Wisdom to fill up the long useless Blanks of Life! Tir'd by our selves, with others soon uneasie, a while with Books we trifle Time away; but ev'n that solitary Pleasure grows insipid, and often wakes the Cares it should beguile; whereas, he that knows nothing, doubts of nothing! So, Cowley, thou say'st right, and Life is an incurable Disease.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam, if I am so selfish as to break in upon your Meditations! Hearing that my Lord and Mr. Airy were gone to the Club, I was walking this way till they▪ come back; for I guess they'll hardly be able to stay there longer than I did: Well, I should be sicker yet of the Country than of London, were there no better Society there.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You'll find that scarce enough, I doubt, Mr. Railmore.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, yet some few Men and Women of Sence, I hope will make me amends.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Women here! Why, Romances, Chaplains and Simplicity, or rather Rusticity, spoil more of 'em for Conversation, than Affectation does at London.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Nay, as for Simplicity, Madam, 'tis a Stranger to this Family at least; if 'tis not one in so fair a Lady as your self to be an Enemy to Man.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Not while Man is such an Enemy to Woman.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: 'Tis pity you're so prejudic'd against us all; for some one might have Lov'd you on the Square, and thus have prevented that Rough, Scornful, Melancholick Air that frightens away the Love your Face and Sence attract.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What, do you believe Love makes us more agreeable▪ Mr. Railmore?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Certainly, Madam, it wears away gently all our Native Roughness, gives a pleasing Turn to our Expressions, a taking Air to our Person, and winning Graces to all our Actions; nay, I'll maintain it makes a Woman more Beautiful.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: More Beautiful! Nay, now I doubt you are more a Dissember than I thought you.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Why, Madam, as I speak to a Woman of Sence, I can prove my Assertion: Pray is not the Face the Mirror of the Mind?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Without doubt it should be so.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Does not then a Mind given over to cold Indifference communicate a certain Lethargy to the Face, that makes ev'ry Feature lifeless and unactive, and spreads a chilling unlovely Air over the whole Person?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: This is somewhat likely, I think.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Now on the contrary, a single Spark of Love happily kindled in a youthful Heart, makes the Imagination quicker, the Wit more free, the Conversation more lively, the Eyes more sparkling, and diffuses o'er the Face that sprightly moving Je-ne-scay-quoy, whose Charms 'tis impossible to resist.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Since I was Born, I never was so strangely tempted to make a Tryal of this.— Aside.— But seriously do you believe, Mr. Railmore, I should look more tolerably if I shew'd less Averson to your Sex?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Give me leave to convince you now of what I said; but first be pleas'd to let your Woman give us a Song that may divert you from more serious Thoughts:
Your Dress too shou'd be artfully loose, and carelesly Genteel; for Love neglects us, when we neglect our selves.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, for once I'll humour you in your Frolick: Sing us a Song!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, what I am doing? I like this Woman strangely, but then I— Aside.— hate the Nuptial-Noose as much. She's vastly Rich too, and I have scarce enough left to Live. What shall I do? If I Court her in Earnest, I may be made her Jest, and all the World's. Thus Love begins by Fooling, till we Fool our selves; and what is worse, we know it, yet go on.

lg.head: A RONDEAU.
lg.l: MOrtals, learn your Lives to measure,
Not by length of Time, but Pleasure.
Now the Hours invite comply;
While you idly pause, they fly:
Blest, while a brisk pace they keep,
But in Torment when they creep.
Mortals, learn your Lives to measure,
Not by length of Time, but Pleasure.
Soon your Spring must have a Fall:
Losing Youth, is losing all.
Then you'll ask, but none will give,
And may linger, yet not Live.
Mortals, learn your Lives to measure,
Not by length of Time, but Pleasure.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, Master, am I now as I should be?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You only want seven or eight Patches: They are to Women what Shades are to Pictures, or Stars over the Face of Night; a Beauty's no more compleat without 'em, than a Beau is without Pouder.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Fye, they should be as scandalous now as Velvet-Scarfs, or Velvet-Faces those greater Patches: Sempstresses, Barkeepers, Chambermaids and City Beaux, wear 'em.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: There's no harm in a few for all that; but I wou'd not have you like my old Lady Tawdry, whose fat Face looks just like a Gammon of Bacon stuck over▪ with Cloves, with more Patches on than she's Years old, over her double Mask of Hypocrisie and Paint.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, how d'you like me now?

div.stage: She puts on some Patches, and makes Sign to her Woman to leave her, and she leaves 'em.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Why, you'll soon bid fair for a Place among the First Rates; chiefly now there are so few! Well, be pleas'd to sit, and do but remember to Hear me, Believe me, and Answer me sincerely. I intend to speak to you, as 'tis suppos'd a Person wou'd do, whose Wealth and Merit might embolden him to make his Addresses to your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I set little Value upon Wealth, true Merit affects me much more; so Mr. Railmore, pray speak as of your self, and do not personate another.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Since you are so kind, Madam, as to prevent my hopes, and give me leave to profess the Love I have for you, I'll wave all those Hyperboles, so commonly lavish'd in Declarations of Love, and all the Hell of Pain which whining Fools, and designing Knaves pretend to feel, and really deserve.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: All exploded thread-bare Cant, to be cast off, like dull Romances, and only us'd by Pedants and Abigails.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I'll neither meanly Cringe nor sawcily Presume; neither magnifie your Worth by Flattery, nor debase my own by affected Dispraise, or Self-Commendation: No, Madam, the only Eloquence, I ought to use to perswade a Woman of your▪ Sence, is my sincerity in doing Justice to your Merit: Thus I only urge the Esteem I have for you, to claim your Ladyship's.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: 'Tis the surest way to gain it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: And if I ever obtain that Blessing, you'll never find the least Unevenness in my Temper, the least Contradiction in my Sentiments, or Decay in my Affections.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Were this possible, Sir, I must own 'twou'd be as singular, as sweet.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Can you wrong me so much as to doubt it, Madam?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: We easily doubt of what we wish.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Think more favourably of a Man whom you have always found to speak his Thoughts, and who being tir'd with long Wandring, and ripe for a Retreat, wou'd fix a grateful Heart, and be for ever True.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sure you forget you are a Man, Mr. Railmore! What, cou'd you Love a Wife, none but a Wife, and that for ever too?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Yes, Madam, cou'd that▪ Wife resemble you so much as to be thought your self: But that's above my hopes: Yet our equal Aversion hitherto to Marriage, to Fools▪ Flattery, and the Hurry of the World, shows two Humours so suited to each other, that they would seem but one, if both were joyn'd: And as each of us at once wou'd Conquer, and be Conquer'd, such an Union of two Marriage-Haters cou'd be but Honourable and Sweet to both. we'd pity wretched Couples, link'd by the poor Sympathy of Interest, or Frenzy; while you and I, clasp'd in each other's Arms, wou'd
think we two engross'd all the Delights they forfeit, and Life and Love can give— Oh do not turn that Lovely Face aside; or I shall think you're made of Ice indeed, and hate my self for being not like you.

div.stage: She turns aside, and looks in her Glass, and sighs.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: By Heaven! He has kept his Word: I Blush to think on't, yet almost wish he might be in Earnest.— Aside.— I Vow, Mr. Railmore, you act your Part so well, that Truth it self cou'd scarce have mov'd me more.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: By Heav'n, Madam, 'tis real all; and to prove it with a Witness, I'll send for some living Form of Sanctity to confirm it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What, are you then come to the End of Love already?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: No, no, dear Madam, I wou'd only come to the Seal of it. Consider if our Sexes Passion ends before yours; 'tis chiefly through your Coldness at first, and your Fondness at last. We set out too soon, or you too late; and you either Starve Love, or overload it so, that the poor Thing seldom holds out to its Journey's end: But you and I setting out together, our Loves shall keep pace with each other, and their Race, and that of Life be the same.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But will not the whole World laugh at us?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: The Thought on't moves me a little, I must confess: But what's the World, the Vile Mad World to us? Besides we may be a while as private as you please, and Laugh at those who vainly hope to Laugh at one of us.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, I must needs own you're an excellent Master, since you have in so little a Time made me look less disagreeably, and almost perswaded me, a Man may be worthy of being Lov'd. Cou'd I believe you such——

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Oh! I am wild to convince you of it more feelingly. Let me seize that fair Hand, and bribe it with fond Kisses, to be a Pledge to mine of a Return. Ah! let me, let me in this sweet, this wise Extravagance of Passion, kindly force you to come and make it lawful now.

lg.l: Too long in vain against your Heav'n you strove:
The only Care that should a Woman move
lg.stage: He draws her along half complying.
lg.l: Is to be fair, to be belov'd, and love.

div.head: ACT V.
SCENE, a Room.
div.stage: Enter Kitty in Page's Clothes, and Frankly in Chambermaid's.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: WELL, you have made me put on Page's Clothes, but I can't put on Page's Assurance. I tremble, and have not power to go.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What! afraid to go and be married to the man you say you love?

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: No, rather afraid my Sister should hinder it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: There's a grave Gentleman in black hard by, who'll soon put that out of her Power, and then you may easily get out in this Disguise.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p:
Nay, I was forc'd to tell her a fair Story to get from her: she believ'd me presently, for, I thank Heaven, she never could catch me in a Lye, and yet I tell I don't
know how many e'ery day: But what will she say when she finds I have deceiv'd her?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Psha, whom do we not deceive to be married? Think o' the Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Well, let's go, I fancy I was not made to be a Nun.

div.stage: Enter Sir Tho. Gaymood, Sir Topewell, and Illbred.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I tell you I have taken care my Daughter shall entertain him as she ought: I have injoyn'd her to think no more of my Lord Lovewel. But see! here she comes.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Daughter, you know what I said to you: Make much of Squire Illbred for my sake, more for his, and more still for your own. Come, Sir Topewell.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Go go, get you gone, I must stay a little to hearten him up.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Will you be pleas'd to sit, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Thank you, Madam, I am well as I am: I love to be in a standing Posture.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: What, won't you sit by your Mistress, man?

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Now I think on't, I don't much care if I do; nay, and lye by her too.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Mark that! heighboy! To Fran.— Say something to her!

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: We've had a fine day to day.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But an odd one, Sir, in my Opinion.

sp.speaker: Sir Tope.
sp.p: Speak to her, good Lad!

div.stage: To Ilbr. aside, and Ilbred jogs him again angrily.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Why, the Roads are as dry as these Boards.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p:
Ay, and the dryer they are, the dryer they
make us: Wou'd I had a Bumper or two of that▪ Hock! Aside. Speak to her, I say.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, what News d'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, none that's good: A Friend of mine is importun'd to marry a man she does not love.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Is that such ill News? Why, 'tis as common in Marriage to hate at first, and then love, as 'tis to love at first and then hate. Cosen, to her! Odsooks thou'rt at least a quart too low. When first I went a wooing, I made my self half drunk, and then I spoke up as boldly as a Member that either scorns or wants a Pension.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Well, when once we're got acquainted, I'll mend my Hand.— Pray, Madam, how old may you be?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You shou'd never ask a Woman her Age, Mr. Ilbred, lest she answer you false, or disoblige herself.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Cry mercy, I meant no more harm than a man that cheapens a Horse or a Mare does, when he asks how old 'tis: I ask'd, because I fancy you and I are much of an age, and thus may the better be yoak'd together.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: 'Tis not likeness of Age, but of Inclination, that makes the Yoke easie, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: I've nothing to say as to that; but if Somebody loves Somebody, as well as Somebody loves Somebody, I know what I know.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What's that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Why then Somebody will have Somebody, or Nobody, inspight of Every body.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: 'Tis well if any body can understand you.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Look you, that is, if you love him as well as he loves you, 'tis a March; tho' this same Lord we saw here thought to have huff'd him out of you, and forg'd a Letter as from you, to make us believe you'll Cuckold my Cosen, yet he dares venture on you, nay, and take you, tho' you had not a Smock to your Back.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My Lord, contrive a Letter as from me.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Ay, that he did; his surly Companion show'd it us. Well, what say you? Nothing? Well! I find there's one Woman in the World has not too much Tongue. Cosen, say as I tutor'd you.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Look you, Madam, I an't us'd to make Love, and mayn't talk so much like a Courtier (never the worse man for that) I am downright Dunstable, I've for these many Months hoarded up——

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: A Barnful of good hearty Country Love for you.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Unkle, hold you your prating Tongue, will you; or rather get you gone; John the Butler, your old Pot-Companion wants you: I'm in now, man.

sp.speaker: Sir Top.
sp.p: Then push it home, Boy. God b'w'ye.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: I fancy I can talk better now the old Sot my Uncle has left us. Faith and troth, I lov'd you this great while, and if you'll be rul'd by a Fool, e'en have me, I dare say you'll be Mother of many Children▪ What say you? Come, as the new Song has it, Here's my Heart, and here's my Hand too; all that's mine shall be thine, Body and Goods at thy Command too. Sings. Odsbobs, now I'm in, you shall see me jig it away: I've got Musicianers just by: Soho Fidlers! play me a Lesson; come, Roger a Coverly, a Jig, any thing, play your May-day Tune, Tom Crowder.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Now go about your business, and leave me to manage mine: O sweet Mistress Frances, I long to be at another sort of Dancing with you; faith and troth I've lov'd you this great while.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I'm afraid the Clown will prove as impudent at last as he was shamefac'd. Aside— Sir, you surprize me with the News of your Love.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Odsbobs, is it a News to you? Why, I've been at Church, and what business could I have there but to see you, think you? I've hunted by you▪ all▪ along to the same intent, and us'd to hollow in a Morning, to wake you, that you might know on't, thus, So-ho!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The noise was the only Instance of your Love that ever disturb'd me to this day; but I'll beg another: 'Tis my first Request, so I hope you'l not deny it.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Nay, to be sure I must do as you'd ha' me, that you may do as I'd have you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Then, Sir, that first Request is, That you would be so kind as to leave me, and think no more of me.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Look you, Madam, I was told you'd be as shy as a high-metal'd Filly when she's to be back'd first; but troth, you may kick and wince, and stand up an end, but I won't be thrown off the Saddle, I won't budge a Foot as long as my Name's Ilbred.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Now I think better on▪ t I must humour you. A good Evening to you; but I'll be with you sooner than you think.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Sir, Sir!

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: I'll be with you anon; I must go look after my Horses.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You have a mighty Ascendant over this Gentleman, my Lord; he leaves the Room as soon as he sees you.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: You have a greater over me, Madam; nothing▪ could make me leave you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But my Father, who ought to have the greatest Ascendant over me, commands me to leave you to entertain him.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: But my Rival is kinder than your Father, and leaves me to entertain you. Ah, Madam! while you stint me to bare Friendship, must he engross the Treasure of your Love, which he wants Sence to value as he ought?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The less Sence a Man has▪ the more he prizes Things whose worth is only imaginary. And after all, my Lord, he gives me no small Proof of his Esteem, in offering to ease my Father of the Charge of my Person, without a Portion to support that Charge. He uses no ill means to obtain me; he did not cause a false immodest Letter, written as by me to himself, to be shown his Rival, to deter him from pursuing his Intentions.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: I do not know that he did so.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I say he did not, but I know who did.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: Tell me who did, that I may punish him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He needs no other Punishment but Neglect. Farewel.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: Going! What can this mean? Stay, Madam, explain your Riddle.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You, who did all this, need no Explanation.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: I! by all that's true, I know nothing of this, and blush to think you can suspect me of it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: There's more than Suspicion, I'm assur'd of it.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: Hold, Madam, do not persist in thinking me so base as to deny the Truth, or I shall cease to think you what I thought you, and strive to grow indifferent. But tell me, who laid that mean Contrivance to my charge?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You would show your Resentment of the Discovery, but I need not tell you.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p:
Nay then, I am convinc'd this is a meer Pretence for leaving me. 'Tis kind however to lessen my Sorrow for so sensible a Separation by ill usage. Well, Madam, I am yet too much disorder'd to have power to expostulate
postulate with you: Farewell. Be as happy as you make wretched; I've nothing now to court but an honourable Death.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Stay, my Lord, let's reason a little more calmly of this business.

div.stage: Enter Gaymood singing, Railmore, and Plot.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Ah! give me more, give me more, &c. Heyday! Gravity has doubled her Guards here to day! O'my word they both look as sullen as a new-married Couple, that find they've cheated one-another.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Perhaps they find they've done so without marrying.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: What, still sighing, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: Still sighing, because still unhappy.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: And still unhappy, because still in Love.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Gad, if I were in your place, I'd no longer be in Love, that I might no longer be unhappy.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: Those that are in Love, and blame others for loving, are like those who are in Health, that blame others for being Sick.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Well, well, have a little Patience, we have been plotting that you may be quickly cur'd.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: How! perhaps then you may know something of a Sham Letter! say, do you? Nay, quickly tell me, I'm all Impatience.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Why, perhaps we do, perhaps we don't; I won't tell you.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: But the Lady accuses me of showing.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p:
Psha, Psha, showing is necessary sometimes; the Lady is a Fool, My Lord: keep your Breath for her; go, get you gone together, be addressing and redressing, pressing and caressing, trying and denying, flying and lying,
cooing and shewing; but first be you going, that we may be doing.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: But my Innocence—

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Shall appear as white as Curds and Cream in nine and twenty minutes. The Grove is a pretty place for cooing Lovers; wou'd you had the Wit to make use on't so long.

sp.speaker: L. Lo.
sp.p: But———

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Lord, will you ne'r ha' done? I hate a man that makes so many words.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: Well, Plot, are all things ready?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Yes Sir, but I fear your Tom will scarce be taken for Mrs. Francelia, tho' the Squire's as dull and credulous as a London Mob: If you could but get one of the Maids to pass for her in the dark, my Comrade can marry 'em by Rote, as well as the best Hedge-Parson between Marybone and Dukes-Place: The Rogue has such a mind to be married, that none can have the Form by Heart better than he; no, not a Maid of eight and twenty, nor a Widow of three Husbands.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: What shall we do? Ilbred and his Uncle will be here presently, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Catso! we wanted some body to fit a Squire, and who should come in the nick but a Chambermaid! Leave me to manage her: Away. Exit Railm. Plot, listen you Dog, and come in when you judge 'tis time.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, we Waitingmen need not be bid to listen, we do it as naturally as Drawers, Landladies, Chamber-maids, or Informers.

div.stage: Plot goes and peeps by the Door.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: How now, my skittish piece of Chamber-stuff, have I caught you at last?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Pray Sir, let me alone.

div.stage: he holds her by the Arm.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: To Morrow Morning.

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: I vow and protest Sir, I'll call.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Let it be so softly then, that no body may hear thee.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Let me go Sir, what will you get by keeping me here?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Not a Maiden-head, I dare swear.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Come, fear not, I'll be very kind; I swear I love thee.

sp.speaker: Plot,
sp.p: So do I, as a Politician loves an Informer, for our own Ends.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I assure you Sir. I'm none of those; Pshau, let me go; are there not Citizens Wives, Masks, and other naughty Women enough?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Toast me, if they ben't as scarce of late, as honest Attornies. What for Sea Captains, Land Officers, and City Beaus, there's scarce a Wench to be had for Love or Money.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: That's a Lye, as too many can justify.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Have a care, thou'lt have the Green-sickness; gad, I love mightily to prevent it, Child, but the Devil shall cure it for me. But I have another Proposal to make to thee.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Pray Sir, don't keep me here; I assure you I am honest.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: What will this World come to! O the Impudence of a Chamber-maid that wou'd scandalize her Calling!

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p:
Hark you, Prethee what woudst thou be honest for? hah! Don't hundreds of batter'd Town Wenches get rich Husbands at last? Don't notorious Rascals jump into good Places, and detected Knaves keep their old ones, or get better? Don't we see cheating Collectors, squinting Bribe-mongers, embezling Pursers, long-winded Pay-masters, saggoting Officers, Brokers and Retailers of Offices
and Benefices, Pimps, Stallions, Catamites, and the Devil and all of Rogues look big, ride in Coaches, respected and waited on by the Croud of honest scoundrel Fools, that trudge it on the hoof? honest! ha, ha, hah!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well, when you can make me live like one of these fine Folks, perhaps I may talk to you.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: So, I knew 'twou'd come to that: Upon my honor, we poor Rogues cannot afford to be honest.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Look you Child, I'll put you immediately in a way to do it. Thou shalt marry Squire Ilbred, whom thou saw'st here to day, a Man of 3000 l. a Year; Nay, and a Fool to boot. That is, provided thou'lt let me confirm him my Fool, as soon as Marriage has made him thine.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sure Sir, you jest, 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: To deny me, you mean. Look you, he loves my Neice Francelia; and we have contrived it so, that he believes she's to marry my Lord this Evening in the dark, for fear of my Brother. The Squire is to come in my Lord's stead and wed her. Now you shall be introduced in her Place by my Lord's Man, who manages the Intrigue, and so she'll be secur'd to my Friend, and the Squire to you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Oh! but Sir.—

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Oh! but 3000 l. a year! say no more, it must be so; or— Oh! here comes the Man shall direct you

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well, I can't avoid complying, as things stand; the Consequence cannot be bad, what ever comes on't

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Plot, Here's Fanny shall act my Neice, and Wed Squire Ilbred; be sure the Parson and you whisper all the while. As soon as you have done, we'll all come in and be Witnesses But hark you, Sir Pandarus; if you offer to be familiar, take notice, I'll make a Capon of a Craven.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p:
O-law, Sir! upon my honor, I'm not so ill-bred
as to offer to be served before my Betters: I'll immediately leave her with the Parson.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Hah, ha, hah! I can but laugh to think how I shall fool both Parties with one Plot, just as all other Match-makers do. The Chamber-maid shall fool the Squire, but I'll fool the Chamber-maid. The Jade was honest just as others are, till a good Bribe came in the way.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: What, alone, Squire?

div.stage: claps him hard on the back.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Not till you came, Knight; I was a thinking.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: That's a wonder! prethee, thinking o' what?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Why, only of bribing a Woman to cuckold the Fool her Husband on her Wedding Night; for I find nothing but a Bribe will do't. A Love Suite now is like a Law Suite, he that courts without Fees, starves his Cause, and sues in forma pauperis.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Did not you tell me once you ne're gave a Wench any thing?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: True, there's the business, I wou'd bribe her at another Man's cost; for I love as little to fee Wenches, as to bribe Lawyers; dam me, I hate to encourage Vice.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Well, Sam, wil't speak a good word to thy Neice for honest Bob.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Between you and I, honest Bob, 'twill be needless; I fancy my Lord Lovewel will have her before to Morrow Noon, if he has her not by this time, and so I leave you.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: I find this same Gypsie-fellow told us true, Cuz. she's to be married in hugger-mugger. I wish he'd come and make good his promise.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p:
Ods bobs, tho' she frumpt me, I fancy she's only strange at first, like other Cattle; but she has a strange way with her, let her say what she will, I cannot but like her. Well, I'd be content to leave off riding hard, and drinking
hard, a whole Week, so I might but get her in a Corner, or on a Hay-cock, and no body▪ by.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, are you come? you're too late▪

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Ods lidikins, don't tell us so Man: Why, 'tis not half an hour since I left her. O law! O law! I could weep like any Calf now.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: If 'tis done, 'tis done; come away, and drown Sorrow; thou shalt go home as drunk as if thou cam'st from an Election.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Hold, hold Sir, I did but Jest with you; but a Moment later had been too— Well, Mrs▪ Francelia waits for me to take her aside, and my Lord is with her Father, discoursing about you and her. Come▪ now's your time, make no noise.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Come along, I'm as still as a Mouse.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Here my Vnkle desir'd us to stay for him; but I can't guess his Design.

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.p: Design! Why, he has as seldom any, as our Modern Play-Writers, unless it be to make us talk as he does himself.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: To no purpose.

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.p: But '●will not be my Fault, if we do not talk to the purpose▪ Madam. Love, Love, Madam! Nothing's to the purpose but that.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Nay, no Love in earnest; good Mr. Airy; don't I know you're a meer Weather-cock?

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I may be like the Weather-cock; for I never change till that which moves me changes; and all my Motions wait upon your Breath. But here▪ most Women are like our Weather, scorch us and chill us the same day: And others make Love so tedious a Plague—

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: As if there were not Plagues enough in Life, without making one of Loving; but some of you make as much haste to get out of Love, as they do to get in Debt.

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.p: I am not for running so fast; for as one said, going to his Wives Funeral; What need we make a Toyl of a Pleasure?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Come, come, most of you serve your Mistresses as all People do their Guests: At first the Entertainment is warm and costly, but soon grows as cold as dull indifference or jaded Matrimony can make it.

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.p: But I am for a love easie and agreeable, like your humor, and that must be lasting. Such a Love, Madam—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Is as indifferent a Love as one can wish, and in Truth, no Love at all▪

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.p: No, Madam, 'tis a pretty, sociable Passion, like modern Friendship. It cheers a loving couple when together; yet is no pain to 'em when asunder. 'Tis like Fire in a Flint, it lyes till 'tis urg'd, but then it never fails to sparkle.

sp.speaker: C. H.
sp.p: Never Court One of our reserv'd Beauties, Mr. Airy, she wou'd expect a stricter Duty from her Lover.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Yes, First he must be a Slave to Dress as much as she is to her Complexion, and never see her unless he's as Spruce as a Dancing▪ Master at his breaking up, or a politick Beau on a Birth-day at Court.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Ay, for I heard of a Beau that lost a Lady for offering to approach her in a Coat with Pocket-holes an Inch too high, and Button-holes but Three Inches wide.

div.stage: Enter Gaymood, who goes towards the Door and opens it. Sir Topew, Square Ilbred▪ and Frankly appear, and Parson Humdrum behind 'em.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Now you shall have sport.

div.stage: He says this, and goes towards the Door.

sp.speaker: Air.
sp.p: To promise Sport, is the way to spoyl it.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: What's he going to do?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, you must not Marry her.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: No more he must not; he has Married her already.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Yes, Faith Unkle-in-Law that is now; you come a Day after the Fair; Here's my lawful wedded Wife, and your—

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Brothers Maid, Brother-Sterling that shall be.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! You're merry dispos'd Unkle: Why, don't you know your own Neice?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Yes, better then you know your own Bride, it seems: Look on her in the light.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Hah! What art thou?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Even what you said just now, my Dear, your lawful wedded Wife.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: The Devil's rather. Ods bobs, do you take me for a Changling? I was Married to Mrs. Frances.

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Nay, thy Wife's Name's Frances; She's the Changling: But my Cousin Francelia has not been in the Room this Evening.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: I'm in Amaze! Or, I Dream, or, I am Mad, or else I'm Drunk.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You have had my hand ever since the Good Man joyn'd us, and Here's the Ring.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Nay, then I'le hang my self, O-law! O-law!

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Oh fye, what a filthy Death you've chosen? Remember you're a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: What, cheated! There's Conjuring in't. Hah! is't so, thou young Witch?

sp.speaker: Gay.
sp.p: Come Knight, speak more kindly to your Niece; he has Married her you know, you're a Witness to't your self.

div.stage: Enter Railmore and my Lady Single, and Plot behind'em

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: What's the matter, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p:
Why, Mr. Ilbred has committed Matrimony with
One of the Maids, and wou'd perswade us 'twas my Neice Francelia▪ that's all.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: This shan't pass so, d'you see.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: No, 'tis past already, d'you see: How will you help your selves? The Gudgeon that's caught in the hook may flounce, and flounder, but that wont do. He hugs it, and tugs it as a Man does his Wife.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Hark you, Sir Topewel, and you Mr. Ilbred, I'le show you I'm not so much your Enemy as you Imagine: I fancy, I have One way to bring you off.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: How? ah, wou'd you cou'd▪

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: If you'l bind your self in a Bond of Twenty Thousand Pounds, never to pretend to Mrs. Francelia, I'le try what I can do for you.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Ay, with all my Spirit, and thank you too.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Here's a Bond ready drawn; look on it, 'tis but Signing and Sealing.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Ay, ay, he shall Sign it and Seal it, and with more joy than any ever Sign'd a Contract of Marriage; here Cuz, Sign, Sign and Seal; but lets see if 'tis right first? heigh ho! how soon care comes upon a Man that's Married! he's no sooner noos'd but he'd give his Ears to get off. Here 'tis Sign'd and Seal'd.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Take off the Seal; you deliver this as your Act and Deed, for the use of the Party therein mentioned.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: I do. Well, now, dear Friend of ours, prythee tell us quickly, how shall I get off? Pray put a Body out of pain!

sp.speaker: Ra
sp.p: Look you, before this Company, I declare you free to Marry any One that will have you, except Mrs Francelia: For, as we got this Maid to Personate her, we got also One of my Lord's Men to Personate the Chaplain.

sp.speaker: Ilb
sp.p: O-law! o-law! Is that all you had to say? You're good to help a lame Dog over a Stile.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Where is he? This is not the Man.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: That's the Man that married me.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Ods death, this is none of Dick; this is Parson Hum-drum.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Plot, Rogue, Dog, how is this? Why sure you did not let the Gentleman Marry a Serving▪ Wench in earnest?

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: As I'm an honest Person, Sir, I cou'd not help it. I had got my Comrade ready according to your directions, and told the Squire and his Unkle so, but they wou'd needs have a Parson of their own, whom they had brought: I did all in▪ the World to perswade 'em not to have him (they know it) but they were positive, and for fear of spoyling my Masters Match, I durst not hinder 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Rogue, Villain, Dog, let me come at him.

sp.speaker: Plot.
sp.p: Nay, then, your humble Servant, tho' I know what I know 'tis time to scamper.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What's the matter Sir Topewel? Mr. Ilbred what ails you?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Why, nothing, he wou'd have taken a Wife with nothing, and he has One with nothing; so there's nothing lost: Tho' he has mistaken your Maid for your Daughter; sure the Maid will be kept Cheaper than the Mistress.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Not when the Maid comes to be the Mistress.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: True; an Usurer's rakish Son, after his Dad's Damnation, or a half starv'd Seaman after his Pay-Day, is not more Expensive,

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Well if he has Married her, let him make much of his blind Bargain.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p: What, and is Meester sped already! Wish your Worship Joy! Here's Doll Hoydon and I are Friends again, an't please you, and want but your Worship's Consent to be Marry'd too.

sp.speaker: Ilb.
sp.p: Here's the Consent I give you, with a Horse-pox.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: ●iey day,! What time o'th' Moon is't? What Wasp, or Nettle has stung him?

sp.speaker: Ga▪
sp.p: Why, thy Master ha● married thy Mistresses Fellow-Servant thro' a mistake, and he is mad at it.

sp.speaker: Hump.
sp.p: What, yonder▪ Minx! Odsnigs, I know what I know; now could I help him at a dead lift, but I have a good mind not to do it, for the sake of this same kick o' the breech he gave me.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: How! canst thou help thy Master off of this ugly Job, Humphrey?

sp.speaker: Hump.
sp.p: Mayhaps I can, mayhaps I won't; what then? You'd give me such another Kick as you did e'en now, wou'd you?

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: Prethee, good Humphrey, don't take it in dudgeon; I'd ha' done as much to mine own mother. Why man, I'm mad. Here, hit me Two Kicks for my One; pray do, pray do; do but bring me off, and kick me till thou'st lost me, an'thee wou'dst.

sp.speaker: Hump.
sp.p: Well, now you cry pectcavi▪ I'll tell you: I and Don was looking for Sir Thomas's Chaplain, to tell him we shou'd want him to give us a Cast of his Office; when who shou'd we see▪ as Luck wou'd have it, but this same Lass there in the high Topping, and a tidy Skip, a little tiny go-by-ground, not passin thus high. (I'm sure▪ she's no higher than a Horse-block) with the Chaplain mumbling over them out of his book; so we listen'd, and found he was making 'em as fast as a Parson can make Two Folks.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Pshau, pshau, sure this cannot be.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Why, you'd as good tell me a Bailiff's no Knave▪ I know her Face main well; D'you think I'm like your London-Folks? tell Lies? I'll take the Bibled Oath on't, and so shall Doll; won't you Doll?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.p: Ay, as I'm an honest body, that I will

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: Ah boys!

div.stage: He jumps, and plays ridiculous Tricks.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Ah boys! Cousin, dance, dance, I say: This brings thee off, boy; and as for you, Mistress Chouse, we'll have you hang'd for marrying Two Husbands.

sp.speaker: Sir▪ Tho.
sp.p: How! is this true, Sweetheart?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, what, shall— as I hope to be sav'd— no— for fear— I can't tell—

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: You can't tell what to say; I find 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: Look you, an't please your Worship▪ here's the Young Smock-fac'd Hobberdehoy she had pickt out for a Cloak: I spy'd him now peeping in here▪ See, he's hardly big enough to go a nutting. I wonder how the man could have the conscience to marry'em. But some of 'em don't value a straw whom they cause to rue, so they're grees'd in the fist▪ Tho I fancys too, they Two had been at other sport than Push pin▪ else he durst not ha' don't▪

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: A beardless boy! Fye, a Husband without a Beard is as unseemly as a Wife with Whiskers.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: He's very Young indeed; but stay— sure▪ I should know that Face▪ It must be my Cousin Kitty! Cousin Kitty!

sp.speaker: Air. Gr.
sp.p: Mistress Kitty!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What, one Female Marry another! Do you make a Jest of Marriage?

sp.speaker: Ilbred.
sp.p: Pray, don't you be Mistress Kitty! Pray don't, pray don't.

sp.speaker: Sir Top. and Illbred,
sp.p: O Law! all's spoilt again; undone, undone!

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: What do I hear, Mr. Illand. Is it possible you've Marryed my Maid for spight?

sp.speaker: Illbr.
sp.p: Only a little by chance▪ I thought to have made sure of you: They have tantaliz'd me twice with the hopes of being my own man again; but that, I fear, I never shall while I live: Yet perhaps you being her Mistress may perswade her.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, she's no more my Servant, since you are her Lord and Master; but tho you should never have been mine, I'm sorry for you: E'en take her with you when you will.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: What, is she whispering already with another man?

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Nay▪ ' be not jealous, Mr. Illbred; our whispering cannot be so fatal to you, as that you had with her, and Doctor Humdrum.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Nay, then 'tis time to be gone! To be thus insnar'd, and then fool'd over and over again with sham promises of getting free is too much for Flesh and Blood to bear. ' Owns! I'll be reveng'd, if I live; come, come away.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Hold▪ you must take care of your Bride, Mr. Bridegroom, for all your huffing.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Nay then if the Bridegroom must take care of the Bride; you and Mr. Illbred must give me leave to take care of this pretty little Partner of mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Take care of h●● and be hang'd; the Devil a bit we'll take care of either.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Well, well, good angry red Nos'd Gentleman, we'll take care of one another.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: What, affront my Nose; you little Snipper Snapper? Odsooks, it cost more a Painting than all the Saffron Faces in a Play-house.

sp.speaker: La. An.
sp.p: How Sister Kitty, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: No madder than your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: She's only Married▪ Madam, and to a person that will strive to show himself not altogether unworthy that happiness.

sp.speaker: La. Sin.
sp.p: How! married in earnest?

sp.speaker: Illbr.
sp.p: Unkle, mind, mind a little!

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.p: Dear Madam, be pacified; the Chambermaid is Mr. Frankly, no more a Woman than my self; but a very worthy young Gentleman, whose Wealth and merit intitle him to a young Lady that has both: He discover'd himself to me now, and told me he was forc'd to use this Disguise to secure pretty Mrs. Kitty to himself.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What the Chambermaid prove a man at last!

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: Huzzah!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Huzzah, Cuz, thou'rt unmarried now: Odsooks let's go and be bloody Drunk for Joy.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: Odsbobs I'm more glad now I've miss'd the wrong, than if I had got the right.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I was inform'd your Ladiship wou'd not suffer your Sister to entertain the least thoughts of a Husband; I got admittance here as a Maid-Servant two days ago; and as you threaten'd her with a Nunnery, she consented the more easily to be joyn'd to me in more suitable Bonds.

sp.speaker: La. Sin.
sp.p: You mean Spirited wanton Girl! Did you then regard my Admonitions no better? 'Tis true, I threaten'd you with a Nunnery, but 'twas but to deter you from marriage, the more fatal Prison of the two. See me no more.

sp.speaker: Kit.
sp.p: Jeeringly. Come, Madam, we guess your Aversion to Marriage is somewhat abated, pray let your Anger be so too. Mr. Railmore, you'll interceed.

sp.speaker: La. Sin.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: In short, we know that the same Spiritual Executioner that dispatch'd us had done as much for you two just half an hour before: So now 'tis about an hour too late for your Ladiship to use that style.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What, my Lady Single married!

sp.speaker: Ld. Lo.
sp.p: Railmore married!

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: The two marriage haters married!

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Nay, then miracles are not ceas'd!

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Why a miracle? I never heard any one rail at the Courtier's Slavish Life, but what would at one time or other Sacrifice his Liberty to it.

sp.speaker: La. Sin.
sp.p: The two extreams Love and Hate touch one another, like Laughing and Weeping.

sp.speaker: Rail.
sp.p: You are all Ephesian Matrons one way or other.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p:
What a Pox, are you capping of Sentences? Wish
you Joy— of a thousand Pounds a year, Jack; for as for a Wife I know better Things than to wish a Friend Joy of that.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Wish you Joy of your Chambermaid here! Did not you say you had had her already, Sam? hah?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Pshau, Pshau, so I wou'd have had her, man; had she been a Chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Cousin, shall I laugh at you two a little, for railing at matrimony?

sp.speaker: Ld. Lo.
sp.p: Pray spare 'em, Madam, they have done well▪ Their Inclinations agreed before, and consequently will now▪ tho a much better way. But now, Madam, to Francelia since I hear, my Rival has oblig'd himself never to raise his Ambition to you, let me beg of you to condescend to make me happy. Sure, Sir Thomas will no longer be an obstacle to this; I had his Leave to urge my suit to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Ay, But I'm loth to part with so much mony at a Time that there's so little.

sp.speaker: Ld. Lo.
sp.p: While Sir Thomas seem'd dispos'd to part with his mony, as well as with his Daughter, it would have been imprudence to have bated him the first. But we'll not differ about it: So, Madam, if you will but at last add your consent to your Father's, I'll ask no other Treasure but your Person, which is indeed too valuable to need any addition to recommend it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: This so generous Offer, my Lord, convinces me of the reality of your Esteem; but to make the best Return I can, I solemnly declare, That if my Father will not be pleas▪ d to part with what he promis'd should be one Consideration of his parting with me to you, I will never consent to marry while I live.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p:
How! Adad, tho I love money, I love Generosity too▪ Here, my Lord, take her, she▪ s yours; the money I promis'd shall be yours too. I must confess, I was tamper▪ d with, and tempted; but there are few here wou'd not have
been tempted to break their word for Ten Thousand Pounds.

sp.speaker: Lord Lo.
sp.p: I humbly thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Wish you Joy▪ Squire.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: Thankyou; but Joy of what?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Why, of being not married; or rather, of being married, yet no Husband: I'm sure many would be glad to be greeted thus.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: I'm so little afraid of being one of those, Madam, that if I can be so happy as to prevail with you to approve of my Love, as well as I hope your Father will of my Circumstances, I shall have nothing more to wish but to be yours for ever.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What, are you making Love in Jest again? To be serious is a Jest. First, let us be sure you can continue some time in a mind: Mistresses, they say, are valued by most of you like Plays, only for being New; You hardly come to see 'em after the Third Day, and it must be an extraordinary one, or an extraordinary Favour, if you come to the House Three Days after, tho your Company's wanted there never so much.

sp.speaker: Ai
sp.p: Oh▪ I shall still discover New Beauties, Madam, and love you more and more.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Pox, you grow too serious on a sudden, man; had you not better make Love in Jest still? The very Boy and Girl in the House will teach you to keep to that. Oh, here they are.— Come Sing the Dialogue my pretty Rogues!

div.head: A Dialogue between a little Boy and Girl.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I play truant to come hither,
To go with you up and down,
I'de leave all the Boys in Town.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: My dear Jemmy, how d'you do?
I'd leave all the Girls for you,

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Come, let's play at Man and Wife▪

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: Fye, you know that's full of strife.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No, we'll kiss and hug each other,
Like my Father and your Mother.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: When you're out, I'll put you in.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Pray, be not so shy, my Diary.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: Keep your distance, or I'le tear you!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: None can see us, do not fear.
Now a little more, good Betty.

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.l: Fye, you make me blush I swear;

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Oh! I cannot, will not tarry.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Very well▪ but I find they are seduced as well as the rest, by the evil Spirit of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: What, can't our Example make a Convert of you?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: No, saith; I shou'd be afraid of the Matrimonial Curse, ●●●●● without stomach, walk about without ease, sing without ●i●th, go to bed without desire, enjoy without pleasure, lie without Rest, be Cuckolded without mercy, ●ught at without pity, and plagu'd without end.

sp.speaker: La. Sin,
sp.p: What, will you never have better Thoughts of our Sex?

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: Ay, when you all cease to go to Prayers without Devotion, to fawn without Love, to weep without sorrow, to be chaste without Vertue, and to get Children without your Husbands.

div.stage: Re-enter Frankly drest like a Gentleman, and Kitty in her own Clothes. Plot behind 'em.

sp.speaker: Ai.
sp.p: Mr. Frankly, now your Friends may know you; you're your self again.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Dear Airy, help me to obtain Sir Thomas▪ s, and my Lady Single's Pardon for using a Stratagem that may seem somewhat inhospitable to those who never felt the violence of Love. As for Mr. Illbred, he must not only forgive me, but honest Plot also, to whom I had made my self known before I was to wed the Squire; so that there was no danger on either side.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: The short and the long of the Stor●●● that between Jest and Earnest I'm fairly chous'd of my Mistress among you, e faith.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Come, come, we'll get thee another▪ Cuz.

sp.speaker: Illb.
sp.p: Get thee another, Cuz! Odsbobs, 'tis all along of you▪ Gnaw, gnaw, you Old Fool: Before George, I've as good a mind as e're I had in my life, to have Susan, Sisters Chambermaid, for spight.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: O fie, Sir, no Chambermaid in earnest▪ I beseech you; come, be thankful; those who take our Mistresses from us, improve our Parts; first we love as Learners, but afterwards like Masters.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Hark you, Sir Topewell, let me give you some Counsel which several men in your station should follow; Allow some needy man of Sence a Genteel maintenance to give your Young Squire good Education by degrees. Let him read good books moderately, but chiefly the great book of the world, not to be found with Pedants. It costs so little more to breed a man like a Gentleman, than it does to breed others like Clowns, that I wonder there are so many of the latter with good Paternal Estates.

lg.l: Good Education must our Youth improve,
And fit a man for Business and for Love.
Wealth may be lost, but never what we gain
By reading Books, and most by reading Men.
Thus we grow wise, and raise and use our store;
While Fops and Squires, amidst their Wealth, are poor.
